TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1996 and an amendment moved by Senator Stott Despoja to schedule 1 item 25. The question before the chair is that the amendment be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —I have moved two amendments to the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No.1) 1996. Last night, when we commenced debate on this matter, there was some confusion as to the financial and other impacts of my proposed amendment. My amendment was to change the two study units per term to one study unit, thus reducing the number of units a student is required to study under the open learning scheme in order to be eligible for the deferred payment option.

SPEECH.PARA: Minister, I take on board your arguments about your scheme offering a degree of flexibility, but I still have concerns about the arrangements under this bill given the move to redefine study periods and to change the semester system. It seems that in the past students had to satisfy a 75 per cent course load minimum in order to qualify for the deferred payment option. It seems that we have lost that concept of the 75 per cent as a consequence of the semester changes.

Can you enlighten me as to whether or not this is your understanding of the bill—that is, it changes that 75 per cent requirement? Given that your officers have had time to determine some of the changes to, and the impact of these changes on, the open learning scheme—and I should add it has not simply been overnight because my office has been in contact with your office on this particular matter for the last week—could you provide any financial details?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just been handed some information in response to some questions you asked last night on this higher education funding bill. I will read that information into the record. It is as fresh to me as it will be to you. The question that has been answered is basically your proposition: why cannot all open learning students defer their fees under the open learning deferred payment scheme? That would be the effect of the amendment you want to move.

SPEECH.PARA: The material provided to me is as follows: the open learning deferred payment scheme commenced in March 1994, 12 months after the Open Learning Agency commenced offering units, to increase the take‐up rate of people studying through the OLA. OLA students are not required to commit to an award course and many undertake study for reasons other than obtaining a qualification. An equivalent situation within a university would be students undertaking non-award courses. These students are required to pay up front and are not able to defer the payment.

BREAK.PARA: The previous government sought to increase access to higher education for students seeking to undertake a qualification who were unable to access a mainstream university place. Therefore, it required students to undertake a full-time load in order to be eligible for the open learning deferred payment scheme. Under OLDPS, students are required to commit to undertaking at least three units of study over two study periods—that is, a semester. The government's proposed amendments increase students' flexibility by allowing them to defer payment for two units in a study period.

Your amendment, however, would allow any OLA student to defer payment. While the concept of open learning has expanded the opportunities for many students to obtain a higher education qualification, it has also created a market for tertiary study unrelated to a qualification. Expanding access to OLDPS to these students is inconsistent with the object of OLDPS. It imposes a further burden on taxpayers who will gain no public benefit from this amendment and will more than double the Commonwealth's outlay. In the period of the forward estimates, this would amount to at least an additional $24 million. There is also a further long‐term cost to the Commonwealth as many of these people will never repay, thus effectively turning the loan or deferred payment into a grant. Publicly funded universities are also significant providers of open learning and distance education opportunities to students. Favourable treatment of a private company, which is what OLA is, with a specified niche market will mean that publicly funded institutions, particularly regional universities, could suffer significant losses of HECS liable students. My understanding of that, in short, is that you are seeking to provide a very special niche for a private company that is not available to other publicly funded institutions who are also offering opening learning access. On that basis alone, I would ask you to reconsider it.

The previous government introduced this deferred payment to increase access for people who were looking to get a qualification and that is why there was some limit there. To move that limit and say, `One unit will do', would allow deferred payment for the `browsing educators'—people taking something that they are not looking to build on towards a qualification. And on that basis as well I would ask you to reconsider. You asked what the cost would be. The assessment I have been given is that the cost of your amendment would be something like $24 million to provide to a private company something that we do not provide to other publicly funded institutions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for her response and for clarifying the financial consequences of this amendment. I understand from your answer that you have changed and in fact the Democrats do support the move from semester to a study period; but in doing so we have lost any concept of the 75 per cent minimum load in order to defer the open learning payment.

SPEECH.PARA: While the minister is conferring, I should put on record that I thought the minister's earlier statement was interesting—that there are students who undertake open learning not simply to gain a qualification or employment. At least that is what I deduced from your earlier statements. However, the Democrats are committed to a flexible arrangement in open learning. We are committed to providing those students with the `mailbox and a television set' as former education minister, John Dawkins, said. We are committed to ensuring that they have access to the open learning scheme, especially those groups who benefit most but may be disadvantaged in a broader context—those with disabilities or those who are in remote areas. We believe that this is indeed a more flexible arrangement in changing the definitions.

On the surface, your amendment does seem to provide more flexibility as a student would be able to undertake say two units over the 13 week period and then choose not to study in the following period but not lose their ability to defer that payment. Our reading of that is that, while it seems fair enough, in reality a student must continue to maintain a full‐time load if they wish to continue to defer their study and work through their course in a measured, ordered and ongoing manner.

Under your proposal, my understanding is that a student must be carrying a full‐time load at any point where they wish to defer their course costs through the open learning deferred payment scheme. So our proposed amendment is to make the minimum study load in order to defer perhaps a little more realistic—one unit per study period—for much the same reasons as the government has chosen to set the standard load at eight units per year. In the government's explanatory memorandum to this bill, `The proposal will continue to ensure that students studying at a distance do not overburden themselves. . . while increasing ease of administration.'

So if you are committed to increasing that level of flexibility—and given that we do not have this change from semester to study period; a study period being set at a period of 13 weeks—substituting one unit for the two units that you have prescribed is indeed a more flexible arrangement and one that would ensure that students do not `overburden' themselves, as you say.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Just two things: firstly, I do not want to labour the point; I am sure you understand the substance of the point when I say that you are asking for a niche to be provided to a private company that is not available to publicly funded institutions. I am at a loss to understand how that is consistent with Democrat policy but if it is, that is fine, that is your decision. I just want to make it abundantly clear to you that that is what you are seeking to do by way of this amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, you drew the assumption in your remarks that the government's amendment will effectively mean that in order to defer payment, you will at any time have to be studying full time. I think that is your version of events and, with respect, that is not correct.
Can I just explain it to you this way. In the previous arrangements, you had to do three units in a semester. We say you must do two within that one study period. But you could, for example—

TALK.START.PARA: —Which is half the length of a semester, is it not?

—I am sorry if I am making you tense. I am trying to explain this as efficiently as I can because I do not want to spend any more time on this debate than is necessary. I have a table here and I am just trying to explain it to you.

BREAK.PARA: Yes, that is right—the study period is half a semester. But you could, for example, do two units in the first study period, none in the second, none in the third and none in the fourth. You could do two in any one study period and none in any of the others. That covers four variations.

Equally, you could do one unit in one study period, two in another and none in the others. That would give you a total of three units in one semester. You would still be able to do that. Or you might do two, none, two, none. Or two, one, one. There are any number of combinations that might suit you because of your workload commitments or whatever.

So we really have increased the flexibility. It is not a requirement for you to do two in every study period, but you must have done two in one study period. That is where the maximum flexibility comes in.

We do say, however, that to go down to one means that you are opening it up to the recreational learner—that sounds dismissive, and I do not mean it that way—as opposed to the person who is a vocational learner. That aspect is not available to the publicly funded institutions. Therefore, we do not think it should be extended to a private company.
That is how the flexibility works. You have to do two units in one study period, but after that the combinations are up to the relevant students. So there is a very big increase in flexibility.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not labour this issue any longer, but I acknowledge and thank the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) for her response. The Democrats simply seek to change that two‐unit requirement to a one‐unit requirement. Admittedly, this would allow for more flexibility. I do not see that we are providing some kind of ridiculous advantage to a private agency. To the contrary, the aim of this is to make available to students that increased flexibility.

SPEECH.PARA: I should say that I do not have a problem with people pursuing education for so-called recreational purposes. If we are committed to the pursuit of knowledge, excellence and academic integrity, perhaps we should talk more about the recreational pursuit of knowledge.

I acknowledge the minister's response. I think it is worth restating that we have changed the definition of the study period. We are not talking about semesters; we are talking about a 13-week study period, so this has changed. I think we have an opportunity to change the flexibility of the arrangements, which the government has gone some way towards doing. We seek to go a little further and substitute `1 unit' for `2 units', as is currently in the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, perhaps I can clarify it for you. It is not simply that OLA is a private company and publicly funded institutions are not. You are saying that you're not interested in that distinction; you're interested in providing it to students. I just want to highlight to you that you are providing it to one type of student and not to all others.

SPEECH.PARA: In publicly funded institutions—until, and if, this bill is passed—you cannot just enrol and do something as a matter of interest. You have to win a place to get into their open learning opportunities. That is the situation with publicly funded institutions.

OLA, however, is a private company, and pretty well anyone can roll up, enrol and give it a go. It is to those students that you are seeking to extend the deferred payment option. It is in that context that I think your view is appropriately understood. This is not something that you are presumably seeking to extend to universities, but you are happy to give it to OLA. That is what I do not understand. You are happy to give it to a private company, but not happy to say that it ought to be available to universities. In fact, it is quite the opposite.

If I said to you that enabling people to buy a place would allow recreational learners to buy a place—not caring whether or not they pass the degree because they simply want to learn—you would say, `No, they're the rich and thick,' and you would not allow that. But you do want to make this amendment to give a special advantage to a private company to allow just that sort of thing in open learning. I am at a loss to see the consistency in it myself.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder whether the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) can outline what facilities are available for open learning under the public system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have a preset package of information available on that, but I am advised by the department that, in most regional universities, about half of the course work—maybe even more—is through distance learning. So it is quite substantial.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Margetts, you and Senator Stott Despoja are not going to allow the recreational learner to buy a place at university. You want to vote against that and stop them having that opportunity. But maybe you are considering Senator Stott Despoja's move to allow deferred payment to other people to learn through OLA, a private company.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a difference, is there not, between open learning and distance learning? How does that work?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —In a sense, it is partly semantics. Distance learning is the term used to describe people who have won a place at a publicly funded institution, as opposed to open learning which does not work on that basis. You do not need to win a place to participate in open learning.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek further clarification. When I was studying in England, I spent quite a bit of time with people participating in the open learning system at the University of East Anglia and found from them that it is actually not a quiet, recreational thing to do. It is actually extremely tough. There have been studies done to show that it is actually tougher getting a qualification under open learning than it is, in many cases, under the system of going to university with other students.

SPEECH.PARA: I am a bit distressed about the idea that it is simply considered to be recreational. Does the minister not consider that one of the reasons why people opt to take a half‐time course option, which is what we are talking about, rather than a full-time course option—that is, one unit per study unit rather than two units per study unit—is that they may have many family commitments? It is not actually a measure of their commitment to the course, to learning or, perhaps, to future use of that. It might be more a measure of their own inability to participate in learning in any other way. It may be that the television is their only option to get that course work in. You might enlighten me otherwise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me take the opportunity to clarify `recreational learner'. It does not imply that it is any easier. A recreational learner may be someone who would like to buy a place at a university—perhaps some retired person who would like to take on a new degree and is happy to pay to do it. To me, being a recreational learner in that sense does not mean that the degree is easy. It means that the person is not doing it with a view to gaining a qualification to get a job; they are doing it out of interest. I certainly do not imagine that open learning is a pushover at all. What you heard from the colleagues you worked with in East Anglia is no doubt as true here as it would be in the United Kingdom or elsewhere.

SPEECH.PARA: My comments do not go to the difficulty of a particular course, but go to the purpose of undertaking it. One of the Labor members of the House of Representatives raised with me recently a research project that had not, in his view, received appropriate recognition and funding. It had in the past, but now it was not going to have continued funding. One of the Australians working on this project is an Australian who was a surgeon and who decided that at 55 he would retire. I assumed from that that he had earned a suitable income from being a surgeon. It did cross my mind that it would not have hurt that person to pay $5,500 as a contribution to a lifelong income that allowed one to retire at 55, to take on another degree to become an archaeologist and to work with a former Democrat senator, Senator Sowada, in Egypt.

That second degree, undertaken by someone who was a surgeon and who amassed sufficient income to be able to retire at 55, was undertaken at the expense of someone else who might otherwise have got in. Under our system, anyone would be able to be a recreational learner, take a second degree when they retired—if they are lucky enough to earn enough money to retire at 55—and pay for it. I want to emphasise that my description of a recreational learner is someone who is not doing it with a view to getting their initial qualifications to get a job.

Secondly, let me repeat: you are quite right when you say that there are some people who, for a whole variety of reasons, will not want to do full‐time study. I thought you asked, `Why will we only fund them if they are full time?' That is not right. They must do one study period—just one—where they take two units. For the remainder of the year, they can take none in the other three periods, or one, or two, or any combination thereof. But in any one year there must be one study period where two units are taken. That is not taking a full-time load over a year, by any stretch of the imagination. A full-time load in any year would be eight units.

We are prepared to fund people who would be doing only two units. That is a 25 per cent load. We are prepared to shift to that sort of flexibility as an acknowledgment of the very point that you raise. We think it is reasonable to say, `If you're doing just over 10 per cent and you're not going to finish for 10 years, then you're not serious about doing this for a qualification. You're not serious enough.' In that sense it would amount to 25 per cent in any one year, and you have to do that by doing two units in one study period. But after that, the flexibility is up to you. You are quite right; there might be periods where it would not be appropriate or easily manageable for someone to do two units in each study period over the year. That might not be possible, and I quite understand that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, on the theme of recreational students, is it not the case—I think it is important to clarify this for the record—that students who are enrolled under open learning have to be studying a degree? They actually have to be in a course and be studying for a degree. It is not a recreational `pick a subject here and there'. They are actually enrolled for the purpose and with the intent of studying to obtain a degree.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that students can enrol in a particular subject. That may build towards a degree. They may do that, but they are not required to do that. That is not the expectation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to add to the points I was making before. There may be a person who, for reason of disability or having small children, was desperate to get a qualification. Firstly, do you have statistics which show that, if a person wishes to take part-time study, that is necessarily related to being a recreational learner? I am not sure that you have given me any statistics that show that. You might have.

PARA.BREAK: Secondly, if that is the case, it may be the wording that is the problem: it says that at some stage you have to study full time. I am not sure what the rationale is there. You could talk about it as an average, you could talk about it over a year or you could talk about it over a semester to give that real flexibility. The problem that is sticking with us is that at some stage they will have to do full-time study. The people who find themselves in the category of those whose only option is par ticipating in open learning may be the people who, for reasons of disability or small children or whatever, may only have the option of part-time study.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think your changes in the bill reflect that level of concern. They appear to give more flexibility. But some people, for all their good intentions and reasons for doing such a course, may not be able to take up that option.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call Senator Sowada. I am sorry, I call Senator Stott Despoja. I went back in time.

—I can understand that, having worked on the open learning bill with former Senator Sowada. I think it is important, as Senator Margetts has pointed out, to note that two units in that study period is the equivalent to a full‐time load. I acknowledge that, in many respects, the government's proposal is to ensure some degree of flexibility. The tables that the minister has read out give students the option of studying certain units at certain times. However, at one point, students, in order to qualify, will have to do that two unit minimum. That is what we seek to replace with one unit to make it properly flexible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Just to make it crystal clear, because there might be some misunderstanding, what you said is right. It is the truth but not the whole truth. The whole truth is that they can defer if they do two units in a semester. They can go on in the other semesters and do no units. They will obviously defer the payment for two. But where they choose to do one unit, then payment for that unit is not able to be deferred. You can defer when you are doing a full‐time load. You are not required to study full time over the whole year. You must do one study period full time and then you can defer. You can do other study units in other study periods, but if you do choose to do that full time you will not be able to defer the payment.

—Thank you for that re sponse, Minister. Can I also seek clarification as to the pass rate. Is it not the case that, in order to qualify for the deferred payment option, students have to maintain a certain pass rate thus showing that they are quite seriously studious and not merely recreational?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —You are right—it is a 50 per cent pass rate. I hope you are not going to suggest that we should fund people with a 10 per cent pass rate. We have all had bad years—
—You said earlier it didn't matter whether they passed courses.
—But in the total of units you have taken, you need to have a 50 per cent pass rate to continue to proceed.

—Again, thank you for that answer, Minister. I refer to Senator Margetts's point that it was not just a case of picking a course willy-nilly and passing or not passing. In fact, students are expected to maintain a certain pass rate and certain average in order to qualify.

PARA.TAB: That the amendment (Senator Stott Despoja's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats oppose the retrospective elements of the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 1) and the basic charge for the Open Learning Agency. The Democrats oppose the retrospectivity of the introduction of a basic charge and a statutory charge set at different levels for the purposes of the OLA. On principle the Australian Democrats are opposed to any form of retrospectivity, any retrospective legislation. I think we are thumbing our noses at the Senate and at legislative processes by passing such legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The office of the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) would be aware of the concerns that the Democrats have on this matter. We have been in touch with her office and with the department regarding some of the correspondence we have had from students who have been concerned about the fact that they had as few as three days warning that they would be required to pay an up-front fee of $93 per unit on top of fees which they might otherwise not be paying up-front or deferring.

That is what the government seeks to legitimate through this bill in item No. 28. We oppose this attempt to legislate retrospectively. We also oppose the content of the changes; that is, to set two levels of fees for the Open Learning Agency.

As we have said many, many times in this chamber, a fee which must be paid up-front has always been a proven disincentive, especially for those groups whom I presume we would want to access open learning the most. I do not think those people should be denied that opportunity because they do not necessarily have the money, and they certainly do not have the funds, to pay up-front. By allowing the continuation of the basic charge set at whatever rate the OLA chooses and the statutory charge, limited to government restrictions, we are leaving students to fall through the cracks—in particular, those traditionally disadvantaged students.

The Democrats oppose retrospectivity. We oppose education policy that is driven by an attempt to make the education sector more privately oriented or to lock those doors and lock access for those students who are from disadvantaged backgrounds or simply do not have the money to pay. We oppose item No. 28. I look forward to the minister's response.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like the minister to explain precisely to the committee the actual operation of item 28. In particular, I would like the minister to respond to Senator Stott Despoja's comments about the indicated retrospective effect of item 28. I would also ask the minister to explain to the committee the government's view as to what effect the excising of item 28 would have.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Stott Despoja, perhaps you would care to respond to this. The advice that I have is that, as a consequence of the failure of your first amendment, you would not want to proceed with this second amendment. What this amendment seeks to do, if the bill went ahead as we want it to—your amendment having been lost—is ensure that people who have taken two units in the December study period and then choose to take one in the March study period would also be able to defer that one unit. If you take this item out, they will not be able to do that. That is as I am advised.
—I thank the minister for that. Is that the advice from your department?
—Yes.

—I was not treating this amendment as consequential. I would return to Senator Harradine's question—that is, the impact of omitting this item 28 from the bill. Would you clarify what your understanding of the impact of excising that item from the bill would be in light of the first amendment having failed?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that, if you are successful in this amendment, people who are now enrolled in three units in a two-one arrangement will not be able to defer that one. This is a transitional arrangement to allow people who are now enrolled in three units—two for the December period and one for the following one in March—to be able to defer that one. You will recall when I came back earlier to you and said, `Part of what I had said was the truth but it was not the whole truth. If you subsequently take a part-time option, you will not be able to defer those units.' That is, if the bill proceeds as planned.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a transitional arrangement to cater for people who had already enrolled in a two-one combination so they will be able to defer those units; whereas if they enrolled in the future in that combination they would be able to defer only the two units. So far from being retrospective, it is actually assisting people by allowing them to complete the December and March units on the basis that they enrolled and on the basis that they thought they would be able to complete them.

My advice is that, if your amendment passes, it will retrospectively take from the students the ability to use the deferment that they otherwise would have been able to. So if you take this item out, it will in fact be retrospective on your part, not the government's.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, would you for the benefit of the committee explain why students have been in contact with my office and presumably with your office regarding what they consider to be very short notice of an up-front fee of $93 per unit on top of other fees that they might be expected to pay? That is a concern that I was hoping to address. I will happily take advice on the consequences of the second Democrat amendment. In the meantime, would you perhaps explain to the committee why students have been faced with this charge and why it has come at such short notice which, as I understand it, was something like three days notice?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —A PPQ was prepared on this in anticipation of my being asked a question by someone such as you during question time. The situation is that OLA has incorrectly informed some students registering for the December semester at short notice that they had to pay the higher fee set by OLA for the March 1997 study period. The department has informed OLA that students cannot be required to pay the new fee set by OLA until after 1 January 1997, and then that is on the assumption that these changes are passed. So OLA did make a mistake. They have been advised of that. I expect they would be seeking to correct it, if they have not already. I do not know how recently you have been contacted. I will just try to get a rough idea of the date the letter was sent to OLA informing of that. I am informed that the letter was sent late last week.

—Thank you for that clarification. So the means by which these students will be contacted will be by letter. That letter is presumably going to all students who incurred that fee at such short notice and they will presumably be reimbursed all of that fee, or have they been overcharged to a certain degree?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering the Higher Education Legislation Amendment Bill 1996, and two government amendments moved by Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone. The question is that those amendments be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —We were in the process of discussing Senator Vanstone's amendments Nos. 1 and 2, which provide guidelines for the determination of the 25 per cent of places for full fee paying undergraduate students. It seems to me that with those amendments we are putting the cart before the horse. Item No. 3 on the running sheet relates to the introduction of full fees for undergraduate students, but the committee has not yet determined whether it agrees to the introduction of full undergraduate fees.

SPEECH.PARA: I wonder if it would be better to move to item No. 3 and work out whether we are going to introduce full undergraduate fees and then go back to the guidelines for implementation. Also, there are amendments in my name which go to the guidelines and to making them disallowable instruments. It might be best if we determine the matter of full fees first and then work out the guidelines further down the list when the issue of guidelines and their disallowability comes up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —There is an initial attraction to what Senator Bolkus has suggested. But, as I canvassed in the debate yesterday when dealing with government amendments Nos. 1 and 2, we indicated in August that we thought it appropriate that universities be able to sell places to Australian students once they had filled their govern ment funded load. With the limitation of those full fee paying students not exceeding 25 per cent of places, quite a lot of people thought it appropriate provided such a limitation was kept because that would stop universities squeezing government funded students out by, for example, in any one particular course, taking 90 per cent full fee paying students.

SPEECH.PARA: Those two things in combination are the mechanisms by which you keep the appropriate mix—no more than 25 per cent of full fee paying domestic students at any one time, and in any one course, not squeezing the government funded students out. We think that is important and that is why we want to increase the number of government funded undergraduate places next year, the year after and the year after that.

I indicated in the debate that some people would agree with that only if we were prepared to show bona fides and put it in the legislation so that it could not be changed. By leaving those matters in the guidelines, which are not disallowable, there would be the opportunity for a government at a later stage to change its view without coming back to the parliament, to increase the percentage of Australian students and perhaps even allow universities to sell places in courses where they had not filled their government funded load. It would be open to a government to do that at a later stage.

The threshold question is whether we are prepared to put in the legislation that any future government would have to come back to the parliament if it wanted to change either of those two controls. I see what Senator Bolkus is saying but, equally, some people would be uncomfortable voting on whether to allow Australian students to buy places unless they were completely satisfied that this matter was dealt with. I do not think that there is a lot in it so I would be happy to proceed as we are, if Senator Bolkus would agree to that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —The only problem I have with that is if opposition amendment No. 3 on the running sheet were successful. Then there would be no full fee paying undergraduate students and we would then have to come back to this particular clause and repeal it, a clause which by that stage would only have had a couple of hours operation.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the Senate should first of all make a decision on whether we support full fee paying undergraduates and then work out the proportion. If we work out the proportion first, that would stay in the legislation while the body of what it is meant to implement disappears down the track. That is why I suggested that we deal with item No. 3 first.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston, Sen Malcolm

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night I was in full flight when I was cut off. I would like to indicate what I had intended to say before that happened. Last night I indicated that I was one of the senators who asked that the 25 per cent limit be put into the legislation. I indicated, not in the same words that I will use now, that it was not the present situation that I was thinking of but some time in the future, with another coalition government or a Labor government or even just a different minister. If this limit were in the legislation it would not be possible to change it.

SPEECH.PARA: I indicated that there was another way around this problem and that was to make the determination disallowable by putting the relevant clause into the bill. I also indicated last night that that would probably not be necessary if this 25 per cent limit were in the legislation. If the Legislative Instruments Bill ever sees the light of day, it is possible that the determination might be caught up by that bill and then be disallowable anyway.

Last night I wanted to make the point that it was not just for now that I was interested in having a 25 per cent limit—it was for some time in the future when there might be a wont to change it. And, if it were not in the legislation, it could be changed without reference to the parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in support of the proposal by Senator Bolkus that it does not make any sense at all for us to be voting on the conditions under which we set undergraduate fees and raffle off the additional places. We should be dealing in logic. We should be dealing with whether or not the Senate accepts that issue and, if necessary, go back to the basis upon which that is agreed. It certainly does make sense for us to deal with that issue first. It does not make sense to put something in a bill which may or may not relate to anything later on. History has indicated that having something like this written into this bill may actually create problems in the future. It certainly has been the case in relation to guidelines.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Stott Despoja mentioned yesterday that guidelines governing the charging of fees to postgraduate students were introduced in 1989, 1990, 1992, 1993 and 1994. They included the removal of prohibitions on: charging fees, fee charging for research degrees and the 20 per cent cap on proportion on fee paying. It is sort of a creeping sore. I do not think it is necessarily the be‐all and end‐all answer, but I certainly would like to see the logic of this argument in dealing with the issue of whether or not the Senate agrees to the imposition of fee paying undergraduate students, and then deal with the conditions under which that should apply if the Senate agrees that should be the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise simply to support that proposed arrangement. I think it would make sense to deal with the issue of charging up‐front fees, and the ability of institutions to do so, before we seek to determine guidelines, and to probably have a lot more discussion at the committee stage regarding guidelines if that other amendment should go through.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I signal that the opposition will be opposing items 1, 2, 11, 28 and 29. We bunched them together because they do relate to one subject and that is the introduction of up‐front fees to undergraduates. There are also indications of opposition from both the Democrats and the Greens in respect of those provisions.

SPEECH.PARA: These are the provisions that would allow universities to charge up‐front fees to Australian undergraduates. Items 1 and 2 amend section 30 of the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 which currently allows the minister to allow guidelines for the charging of fees for postgraduate students. These items simply extend the power to charge fees and to issue guidelines to this effect to undergraduate courses as well as postgraduate courses. Items 28 and 29 make the corresponding changes to the Australian Maritime Collage. Item 11 is a consequential amendment that ensures the undergraduates paying fees are not also subject to HECS.

I say in respect of this—and I said it during the second reading debate—that the opposition has immense problems with the introduction of up‐front fees. We have problems in terms of equity and also the impact on individual students. We are talking here of our long‐held opposition to up‐front fees for Australian undergraduates. Can I also remind the Senate that it was not all that long ago—it would have been within the last 12 months—that the current government, and particularly Senator Hill, also made great play of its opposition to full up‐front fees for undergraduates in this place.

Our opposition is based on the central tenet that access to various professions and career options for young people should be determined by ability and motivation, not by financial means. There are equity considerations involved here. As I said in the second reading debate, there is also some national interest implications as well. We do not accept the analogy with overseas fee paying students. We claim that is spurious because we think it is in our national interest to ensure that Australians do have access—through no up‐front undergraduate fees—to universities and tertiary education.

The government has introduced some amendments to try and limit the extent of undergraduate places to some 25 per cent. As has already been indicated in the debate, the government amendment will set the 25 per cent figure. But we do have quite a number of problems with the way that figure and that imperative is going to be implemented—whether it is cross‐university, cross‐faculty, how courses come in and out of it. Basically, it is something that will need enormously close checking on. To that effect, when the issue comes up later in the proceedings, we will be moving amendments to ensure that whatever guidelines do eventuate, if this proposal gets up, those guidelines under the minister's most recent amendment will also be subject to parliamentary scrutiny.

There are very enormous problems here—problems that unfortunately your government has not focused on in producing this legislation. There are questions like: what will be the impact of this legislation; how would it impact on those who are financially disadvantage; and how would it impact on the target groups that have been of major concern over the last decade or so? All those sorts of issues are pretty critical.

You claim that, under Labor, the system did not produce greater equity. We would argue against that very strongly because under Labor more and people of disadvantaged backgrounds were getting access in terms of numbers. We acknowledge the proportion did not go up, but we also maintain we should look at our record and our achievements as a country in this area, as against the trend internationally where inequity has been basically reinforced in comparable educational systems.

We also have been keen over recent years to see more numbers of women doing non‐traditional courses. That increased. The number of Aboriginals and people of non‐English speaking backgrounds accessing the university system increased as well. These are the people who will be denied in the future because of the introduction of up‐front fees.

Minister, you say that this will provide some greater access to the system but what you are doing is totally different from what we did a few years ago when we introduced HECS. You can shake your head all you like but you can hear it pretty strongly from this side that when we introduced HECS a few years ago, the money that was raised through HECS was applied to extra resources for education.

I do not know how you can nod your head, Minister. You are overseeing in this package cutbacks of some 10 per cent by way of grants to universities, as has been estimated by the Australian vice‐chancellors. I would rather believe them, Minister, despite all your sniping about them and despite all the disparaging comments you make about their being only self‐interested. You did it again last night, `They are sharp when it comes to money matters.' We know they are sharp when it comes to a lot of matters and one thing they are sharp about is being able to see through you and your government's package.

They can see that this is a grab for money. Although on the one hand you claim that the increase in charges and the cuts to education are just a nick, they can see that this nick extends to at least some 10 to 12 per cent in terms of funding to universities. The vice‐chancellors are of that view. You disagree with the fact that they are of that view? You have a different view, obviously, but you do not disagree that that is the estimation they have made?

TALK.START.PARA: —I will put my view.

—You will, later. What we are concerned about is equity in the process. When it comes to a proposal like this we would like to have before us, to make an assessment of equity considerations, some independent analysis. Despite not having comments from you, Minister, we do have comments from across the sector and from people like Mr Chapman, who presided over the introduction of HECS, making it very clear that these sorts of changes that you are pursuing now are changes that will impact very negatively on equity in the system. As he said, the changes to Australia's higher education system announced in the budget have more potential to transform financial arrangements than any other funding policy variations announced over the last 30 years. This includes the abolition of fees in 1974 and the introduction of HECS in 1989.

SPEECH.PARA: We see your changes here as being hasty, ill‐considered, without policy review and essentially driven by a grab for cash which ignores the inequities that this proposal will introduce into the system. For those reasons, we will oppose the items in the schedule to which I referred. I am sure that during the course of this committee discussion we will be able to find a few more reasons, as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will try during this debate not to respond individually because that would take up a lot more time; and I know senators have contributions they want to make. What is being sought from the parliament is a substantial change and it deserves the appropriate time to consider it and a respect for each other's views. I just want to say in response to the contribution by Senator Bolkus that it would have some meaning if the government was looking to cut funding for undergraduate places at universities. But since this government is planning to offer some 6,000 more government funded undergraduate places next year, I think this government is perfectly entitled to say that, under the system we are offering, more government funded students will be able to get in next year than would be the case if the previous government's plans had been implemented. That is just a plain fact of life—it is there in the budget papers.

SPEECH.PARA: We are prepared to have about 6,000 more government funded undergraduate students next year. So let us not confuse this debate with any discussion about it being something to do with equity because people are going to be locked out. Under the proposals for the whole package that we are putting, more government funded undergraduate students will be able to get in next year. So let us not pretend to anybody that somehow people who otherwise would have got in are going to miss out. That is not the case. There will be more people in government funded places—undergraduate places—next year than would have been under the previous government's plans. That applies to total numbers of places and quite specifically to undergraduate places next year. In the following years there are fewer postgraduate course work places but still more government funded undergraduate places.

So let's have no messing up of this debate with an argument that somehow under this government's proposals a whole band of people whom senators opposite might like to take as their cause celebre are going to miss out. No‐one is going to miss out who would not have missed out under the previous government. Fewer people will miss out under this government than would have missed out under the previous government because we are offering more undergraduate government funded places. So let us not tarnish a debate on the principle of whether in addition to those places Australians should be able to buy places with that kind of mishmash.

The additional point that I would like to make comes back to the point that Senator Bolkus was making, that somehow this is devastating for higher education. We had a situation in the past where you either got a Commonwealth scholarship or you paid for a place. Many people think that worked very well. It was changed to say that education would be free to students—not free for everybody; other people would pay. Senator Bolkus was good enough to acknowledge that in that time there was not a significant increase in lower socioeconomic groups—

TALK.START.PARA: —There was in numbers.

—But not in the proportions. There were more numbers of everybody. In the equity sense, did they get a fairer share or a bigger share? No. You were good enough to acknowledge that so I am being good enough to acknowledge that you were good enough. I might think twice about that next time, Senator Bolkus. If you are not going to be generous when I am good enough to acknowledge that you are good enough, I will not acknowledge when you are good enough. Then we shifted to this notion that it would be free for students. As I understand it, there was the expectation that somehow by doing this we could increase the proportions of lower socioeconomic people who otherwise would be shut out of higher education. But it did not work.

SPEECH.PARA: Then we shifted back to a system where people had to pay something. But, as I indicated yesterday, one of the great innovations introduced by Labor—I will be ungracious now, Senator Bolkus; there were not many in the 13 years that you were in, though this was one of them—was that the contribution being sought by students would not have to be paid up‐front or as they learnt, but rather when they earned. That is the beauty of the HECS system—that it allows access irrespective of your income at the time. We want to maintain that.

What HECS did was acknowledge once again that there is a private benefit. There is an enormous public benefit in higher education institutions, but there is a private benefit to the people who go through as well, and we canvassed these the other day. Those benefits are higher incomes, more status in life, a better working pattern and a more secure working pattern—a whole range of things that we do not give to TAFE students and we certainly do not give to school leavers who simply go and get a job.

We give a piece of paper to university graduates that is internationally portable and we spend, at a minimum, about $20,000 on them. We do not spend anything like that on TAFE students, who are no less valuable citizens. We certainly do not give them a piece of paper that is internationally portable. We do not spend anything like that on people who go and get a job and who work as a storeman, packer or whatever they can because we did not provide them with either the opportunities of good enough primary and secondary education or the opportunities to get into the trade of their choice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let alone to start a small business.

—Or people who say that they are going to start a small business. Perhaps they want to run a freight business. They will need to buy a second-hand ute or whatever and do freight deliveries. We do not say to them, `Oh, you'd like a career in the future. Here, quick, let's lend you $20,000 so you can buy a truck. Look, by the way, you only have to pay us a third of that back and we'll lend you that money. Just pay it back as you earn. Don't worry. Struggle along with your business.'

SPEECH.PARA: We do not do that. There are enormous benefits in higher education that the taxpayer puts into this group of school leavers but does not put into people who go to TAFE or to people who go and get a job, and there are benefits they get for the rest of their life. That is what HECS was introduced to do—to say, `Look, you're going to have to make a contribution because the benefit isn't all the public's way. You get some benefit out of this as well.' What we want to do is redress what we think has become an imbalance.

I would like to turn briefly in these remarks to the earlier debate on the open learning arrangements. Senator Stott Despoja rightly identified that she does not condemn what I call recreational learning—that is, people who are learning out of an interest, not because they want to get a particular qualification in order to get a job. The government supports that. I not know anybody in this chamber, for that matter, who does not support that sort of recreational learning.

Senator Stott Despoja says she supports it. She is happy to let people enrol in OLA to do it; she is happy to have the taxpayer fund a deferred payment scheme to these people in OLA—in a private company—but is somehow not happy to let other people engage in that recreational learning at a university, for example, by doing a second degree after they have retired. This refers back to the example I gave of the physician who was lucky enough—and wealthy enough, I suppose—to retire at 55 and go back to university to do archaeology and go off to Egypt to work with Dr Sowada. He is probably living a most enchanted life, I imagine—sending Labor politicians back to tell me that the research program is not getting enough money. Great! That is what the system does.

Senator Stott Despoja is happy for the physician to do that at taxpayers' expense, but she is not happy for us to introduce, for someone who could afford to pay, a system whereby we say, `Over and above the existing government funded places, we'll put some more government funded places. We'll actually increase the number of government funded undergraduate places.' She is not happy with that, because what we are going to do on top of that is say, `Furthermore, if some additional people want to put their own money at risk and buy a place to do a second degree or to get into the degree or university of their choice, we're happy to let them do it.' It was a chance to make the rich pay. Now we want to let them pay and you want to stop them. It seems to me to be insane.

If there are people there who are happy to pay, let us get them out of the government funded places. If they want to move out of a government funded place to a fully funded place for some particular choice, and, as a consequence of that, another person, who otherwise would not have got in, gets into a government funded place, well, we have done a good job. We have done a good job if that is what we can achieve. What about Senator Bolkus's contribution, making a suggestion about the so-called rich, with the term used in a pejorative way. One of the problems with this notion, of course, is that if you have any money people seem to think you are a drug runner or a crook, and that is what is meant by the pejorative of the rich.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come off it!

—Oh, yes, that is how people say `the rich', as if everybody who has got any money is some sort of nasty creature. Here we are trying to get these people the opportunity where they can pay and move out of government places so that the genuinely poor and needy who otherwise might have missed out can get a spot, and you want to stop it.

SPEECH.PARA: But the ultimate insult is to call this a grab for cash. Perhaps Senator Bolkus does not understand—in a way that I know Senator Stott Despoja understands. Yes, she understands, but, Senator Bolkus, you have perhaps missed the boat on this. This money does not come to the government. It does not come through the government with an agency fee taken. Oh, no. This money goes straight to the universities—straight to the universities.

This will go into better lecture theatres, better laboratories, better science labs and more opportunities for all students, including the government funded students.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Newman, representing the Minister for Family Services. Minister, I refer you to the promise made by the Minister for Family Services at the time of the budget that the government would protect older Australians from being forced to sell their homes to gain entry into nursing homes. I refer you particularly to the minister's media release of 22 August in which she stated:

QUESTION.PARA: You will not be forced to sell your home.

She repeated that undertaking in the House of Representatives yesterday. Minister, do you stand by that undertaking? Can you tell us what action the government proposes to take to assist people who find that they have no other option but to sell their family home in order to get into a nursing home?

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, the shadow minister for social security understands full well that the minister and the government have given that commitment over and over again. There is nothing further to add to it. That commitment stays.

—Supplementary question: how can the minister then explain the fact that documents from the Department of Health and Family Services state that the best option for pensioners forced to pay substantial up-front fees to enter nursing care is to sell their family home? Minister, that is a document from the Department of Health and Family Services.

—The Labor Party is hypocritical to the extreme in this matter. Let me answer directly the question that has been asked, which relates to a document that is supposed to be a departmental document. I believe the shadow minister is referring to a document which has not yet gone to the minister, as I understand it. In fact, it is not a government document as such; it is a document based on consultations with the wider community. It has no status in terms of the government's direction at all.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Parer. Has the minister read the strategic study for the international coal industry entitled `Emerging Giants', published by a commercial researcher, Australian Mineral Economics? Is the government concerned about the erosion of Australia's competitive edge in the world coal export market?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank Senator Troeth very much for that question because she is asking a question which relates to our largest export earner, the coal industry, which brings in about $8½ billion a year in export income. I do have some concerns, as everyone does, about any erosion of our competitive edge, whether it be in the coal industry or any other industry, but I am very confident that the opportunity does exist to maintain and expand our position.

ANSWER.PARA: The paper by Australian Mineral Economics points out that Australia will continue to be the dominant force in international coal over the next 10 years. However, the message is very clear that we cannot afford to rest on our laurels and we cannot afford to be complacent. It is worth pointing out to honourable senators that, while Australia is the world's biggest coal exporter, it is by no means the world's biggest producer. The biggest producer in the world is, in fact, China with about 1.4 billion tonnes, followed by the United States at about 900 million tonnes and India at about 400 million tonnes.

The analysis suggests that Indonesia, Colombia and South Africa are the lowest cost producers at present and that strong export growth is expected from Indonesia and Colombia. In fact, when I was in Indonesia recently it was pointed out to me by some of the business people there that they expect the exports of thermal coal from Indonesia to grow within the next decade or so from about 20 million tonnes to 50 million tonnes.

Naturally, I, and I think most other Australians, would like to see that growth occur in Australia. But our competitiveness is questioned due to the appreciation of the Australian dollar, the high rail freight costs and the high labour costs, despite our special advantage in terms of location within the APEC region, which is predicted will be the fastest growing region in the globe over the next 10 years.

The fact is, as noted in the paper, Australia has the greatest capacity to lower unit cost of production in response to any fall in coal prices compared with any of its competitors. High rail freight charges in Australia are set to fall, with Queensland moving to commercial rates and New South Wales moving to a rail access regime to allow a third party to access existing rail freight infrastructure. These moves, of course, are very much to be lauded.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the dollar? What is Costello doing about the dollar?
—Senator Schacht, I call you to order.

—The government has moved to amend the industrial relations laws and these will provide the framework for increased productivity and a challenge for the industry and those employed in it to use the new laws as a springboard for higher productivity and improved reliability. Considering the fact that we are blessed with very good resources, the two key factors in expanding and developing new mines are reliability of supply and productivity. It has nothing whatsoever to do with cutting wages; it is about improving the unit cost of production. Another favourable condition is the government's regime of maintaining a low rate of inflation, a rate of inflation significantly lower than those prospective competitors.
—What about the value of the dollar?

—A perennial problem for all commodities, Senator Schacht, is the adverse effect of a strong Australian dollar, and a margin for currency fluctuation is something that companies should always factor into their plans. They do, Senator Schacht. If you have ever been in industry, you will know that they do get involved in the forward exchange. But the problem underscores the importance of working in the areas where tangible gains can be made, such as micro‐economic reform and productivity. Currency appreciation can bring some benefits, such as where a company has foreign borrowings or when it is importing capital equipment for expansion and new production. In short, the message I see in the study is that Australia will need to continue to look closely at its costs to remain competitive. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs representing the Attorney‐General. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the senator for his question. It is often the case that either the Attorney‐General or the minister representing is asked questions in relation to investigational matters. I think the last one asked in this place of me was by Senator Ray.

Honourable senators interjecting—

Kim Carr, which once might have been called the Bolsheviks but since they are not in a majority you would not call them that any more. Then there is the Pledge group, the Socialist Forum and now Dr Theophanous has this new breakaway faction. It is more complicated than revolutionary Russia. TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, on a point of order. When you actually have to read your funny lines, read the jokes from a written script. Even you, Senator Hill, could do a little better than that. I ask you to call Senator Vanstone to order for reading her jokes.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. The float of the German Telecom last month resulted in an undervaluing of the asset and a windfall gain to the new private shareholders of $3.3 billion at the expense of the former shareholders, the German public. The sale of the second tranche of British Telecom shares resulted in a $3.2 billion windfall gain for its new shareholders at the expense of the British public. Minister, are you concerned that the now privatised Commonwealth Serum Laboratories was undervalued by 67 per cent by the previous government, a loss to the Australian public purse of $558 million? Would you call these share floats successful, as the stock market has labelled them? Should governments have sold their assets for substantially less than their real worth? And what guarantees can you give that, if the worst happens and the Telstra sale proceeds, the Australian public will get full value from the sale?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —I can assure Senator Kernot that those who participate in the float will certainly get full value for money and will be very appreciative of the opportunity. But you seem to have a simple‐minded notion that, if a share rises in value, the person who sold it must have sold it too cheaply. The fact is that there is a lead time involved in making a judgment and in striking the issue price, and a lot of factors can affect the sale price when it finally comes on to the market.

ANSWER.PARA: It is probably fair to say that, once again, those who were responsible for the sale of the first tranche of Deutsche Telecom underestimated the level of demand. In other words, they did not realise how absolutely desperate the population were to get on board and how popular—

TALK.START.PARA: —They sell it at a lower value to make sure it is subscribed to.

—As I recall, it was oversubscribed a number of times and the rate of increase was something like 17 per cent on the first day. If those figures are right, that indicates that there was an enormous demand which bid up the price of the share.

ANSWER.PARA: Just understand this. If you strike a share price at $3 and no-one is interested, you will not get your $3. Why are people interested in buying it? Because they think it has enormous potential for the future. In other words, they predict that the stream of earnings will justify a higher net present value than might otherwise be the case.

The fact that it goes up in value does not mean it was undersold. If you wanted to sell it at such a price that there would be no scope for any increase, you would not get any takers. So you always have to leave a bit there for those who come along later.

It does not mean, in any way, that the Commonwealth is selling itself short if it sells at a price below which the share price finally rises to—any more than you can predict that the share price will rise over time. That depends on performance.

If you look back after six months and find the share price has gone up 50 per cent, you do not say, `Well, they clearly sold it too cheaply.' The fact is that you sell it at the price that people are prepared to pay at the time, and the future movements in that share price will be a function of its performance.

Deutsche Telecom is yet another example of the enormous demand that there is in the marketplace for these types of shares. There has not been the opportunity in Germany for too many privatisations, and this one is a very big exercise. It is going to be followed by France Telecom in the not too distant future. What you are seeing around the world is a recognition that this provides tremendous opportunities for investors as well as for users of the service.

Senator Kernot, you ought to look at this as yet another example of how far out of touch you are. I do not blame just you; it is the crowd over there who ought to be hanging their heads in shame. They are the ones who privatised everything in sight when they had the chance. Senator Kernot, you might not understand all the benefits that could flow, but they do. They know that, by creating a sale price and by creating a market signal, inevitably you will bring pressures to bear, you will drive down the inefficiencies and you will provide benefits to consumers.

That is what it is all about. It is not about giving people windfall gains. There are people who understand that by investing in a company that is on the right track, that does have enormous opportunities and that is free of the shackles of someone looking over its shoulder all the time, like Paul Keating used to do—he would give them a call and ask them to send him a cheque for another $400 million—it can get on with the game. If a company is free of those sorts of constraints, then it can really get on with the game and, as a result, investors will reap the benefits. That is all that is happening. People are understanding the potential of these stocks and they are voting with their feet and their pockets accordingly. I am sure that Australian investors would like the same opportunity. We will not be deliberately selling it short. We will simply be selling it on a value for money basis. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, are you saying that your government has deliberately undervalued assets in order to give this windfall profit to the few? Isn't the average of the undervaluing of assets so far of Qantas, the Commonwealth Bank and the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories 20 per cent? That is $1.5 billion so far from the public purse. And $1.6 billion from Telstra. Why should current owners, the Australian public, subsidise these windfalls for those who have enough money to buy shares?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —Everyone has got enough money to buy shares, Senator Kernot. It just depends on how much you have got as to how many shares you buy. It is a judgment call you make.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—I presume that if Senator Kernot had sold real estate and the value of that property rose 12 months later, she would not turn around and say that she had sold it too cheaply. In other words, it is absolutely ludicrous to pretend that, because there is a subsequent increase in the value of a share, somehow it was sold too cheaply. On that basis, you would argue that every share that was ever sold and that subsequently went up in price was sold badly by the seller. That is not the case at all.

ANSWER.PARA: Sellers sell for a variety of reasons. The reason a share price rises is fundamentally that the demand is there and people anticipate it will do much better. That is the lesson from all these privatisations. People understand the enormous opportunities that will open up when the market is able to control the share price. I hope you will appreciate that in due course. I am sure the Australian public will. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Senator Alston. Minister, can you confirm that you have granted an extension of three weeks to the standard telephone service review group and that the report is now due on 20 December 1996? Isn't the report of this group critical to consideration of the legislation dealing with the post‐1 July 1997 telecommunications framework? Can you assure the Senate that the standard telephone service review group report will be made public on 20 December so that it can be considered in a timely way before the post‐1997 legislation is debated?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —You got the first part right: we have granted an extension. The report date is 20 December. From then on, it tails away. You need to appreciate that we have a capacity to upgrade the standard telephone service definition by regulation at any time. In other words, it is not linked to the current legislation. It is a matter that we obviously do take seriously. We will want to consider carefully the results of that report. I will not be releasing it the moment I get it. I will read it first. I may want to discuss it with people, and we will make sure it is fully out in the marketplace for consideration.

ANSWER.PARA: Bear in mind that it is all about making judgments about the minimum standards that ought to be available, particularly in rural and remote areas, where the quality of service is often very inadequate by metropolitan standards. Whilst there are those who would say we should simply build in compulsory ISDN services, for example, we would rather see those services demand driven. As long as exchanges are ISDN capable, then people will be able to get access to the Internet and other high speed data services.

That is an important issue. It goes to the concept of the universal service obligation, and the bill that will be before the parliament shortly will contain provisions that will expand the range of the USO and will make it even more effective. Within that context, there will be the capacity to upgrade, but not to downgrade, the standard telephone service. In other words, no-one need have any concerns that the passage of the legislation could somehow reduce the current level of the standard telephone service. We are talking about upgrading it—upgrading it on a sensible basis, recognising the disparities that often exist between regional areas. I hope that when the committee reports, it will give some useful advice about how we can improve quality as much as quantity of services in rural areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, can you ensure us that the reason you have not introduced into the parliament the post‐1997 legislative framework is that you have been in long dispute with your backbench over the cabling issue and that you have been promising since late September that the legislation was about to be introduced immediately into the parliament. With only seven days left of this parliamentary sitting, we still have not got this legislation before us, despite the fact that the opposition has offered to refer this legislation to a legislative committee of the Senate for review over the Christmas break so that we can get into a proper debate in early February when the parliament returns.
—I can't `ensure' you but I can `assure' you that we do have an intention to introduce that legislation. We will be doing that very shortly—
—In the next seven days?

—Absolutely. The difference is that we believe in proper consultation and discussion. We do not have the Keating view of life: you get a few heads in the corner, you tell them what you want, you tell them what the big end of town likes and then you deliver the goods. If you happened to be like the hapless former minister for communications, Michael Lee, you would basically do what your master's voice tells you. We do not operate in that fashion. We will ensure that the legislation is in the parliament. Senator Schacht, I am glad that you said you would facilitate the reference of that legislation to a Senate committee, because I think that is a very good idea. The opportunity will be there for the Senate committee to examine it. If you just wait a little longer, I will make sure you get a press release today on the subject.

—Senator Brown, I have said this a dozen times, but I will say it again. The policy of this government is not to mine national parks. —I am glad you agree. At least we agree on one thing. There are areas that can be subject to what they call multiple and sequential land use.
