From recollection—and you can correct me if I am wrong—I do not think there has been one major project in this country, whether primary mining or any other project such as downstream processing, that you have not opposed in the time you have been in public life.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister failed to answer the central part of my question, which related to the government's promise at the election to back a secure and dedicated system of forest reserves. Are you proposing that this secure and dedicated forest reserve system be available to mining? If so, under what conditions?

—Let me respond by saying to Senator Brown that we are committed to the RFA process. It is being handled mainly by my colleague Senator Hill, who I am sure would be only too happy to expand on that. One of the difficulties you might have, Senator, is that Senator Hill and I talk to one another a lot. In most cases, we come to happy agreements with respect to the common goals of government policy.
—That is more than cabinet could do.
—When are you ever going to come up with a constructive idea?

—He is a great source of advice. We are committed to the RFA process. I think Senator Brown would appreciate that, in the main, land use is a matter for the states, not the federal government. In the RFA process there will be cooperative agreements between the federal government and the states.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts, Senator Alston. Do you believe that your imposed cuts on the ABC have resulted in the sacrifice of many local programs in favour of network programs on ABC radio? Has this led to the departure of several high rating presenters to commercial radio? Will this new centralised approach threaten the ratings of ABC radio programs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know what my beliefs have to do with this. Anyway, I will do my best to answer this question. The starting point in this debate is to look at the fact that the ABC recognised that it needed to reduce its overspending by $13.5 million—
—A $209 million cut over four years.

—It seems that you are not aware of this, Senator Schacht. Perhaps you would like to recall your submission and get it right on that point. When are you going to release the submission? We would like to debate that. Will you undertake to table it in the parliament? We will refer it to a Senate committee. We can then have a sensible discussion about your lack of knowledge of the ABC. PARA.BREAK: One cannot quite tell the basis on which programming decisions are made. We think it is perfectly possible to achieve the level of cuts that we have proposed without having any deleterious effect on programming arrangements. The extent to which the ABC goes in for networking rather than maintaining individual presenters is a matter for them. No doubt the viewers and the listeners will make their judgments in due course. If they do not support it, then there will have to be adjustments to the process. It has nothing to do with us. At the end of day, they have to make decisions to fit within their budget. Most other commercial radio stations, for example—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are the ABC's doormat, too.

—I would not waste my time wiping my feet on you. I think he knows as much about this subject as Chanderpaul knew about the last ball before lunch. Your contribution to this debate has to be minimal, I would have thought.
—Not a bad innings.
—It was a good innings, but it came to a halt. I am sorry that you do not look like getting into double figures, the way you have been playing.
—Actually Chanderpaul made 71, Bozo.

—He made 72, actually. Can I simply say that it is a matter for decision and judgment by the ABC how they structure their presenters. A number of commercial stations, for example, have been able to get by with having one presenter for the morning programs. The ABC, until now, have managed to have two presenters in position. If they are now moving into line with the commercials, then that presumably reflects a sensible judgment about what is possible without compromising the quality of pro grams. But these are decisions made by the ABC. I know that if Senator Kim Il Carr had half a chance, he would be in there giving orders to them.
—Senator Alston, please address Senator Carr by his correct name.

—I am sorry, Madam President, Senator Carr. Fortunately, Senator Carr will not have the opportunity to play any influential role in relation to the ABC, nor does it seem he is having much influence in other quarters. The extent to which the whole process of detribalisation is occurring in the Labor Party is a matter for wonderment. We are certainly watching interestedly from the sidelines. —I ask a supplementary question. Can you explain why a network program beamed into Melbourne last Saturday night on ABC radio carried a detailed weather report for Sydney and the rest of New South Wales but not for anywhere else in Australia? Is this an example of the dangers of centralised networking based in Sydney?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —There seems to be some confusion here. I do not know whether Senator Carr thinks that I am the general manager of the ABC or that I am the local production head or the studio manager or something. He is asking me why they got a weather report wrong. Really and truly, I would have thought that if you were interested in policy decisions you would be exploring something a bit more highbrow than that. If you want to write to them, if you want to ask Senator Schacht to write a letter on your behalf, you are more than welcome to do so. But I really do not think that you could seriously expect me to make judgments about that. If you want to have a debate about the benefits of networking, you can have it.

ANSWER.PARA: If you want to argue that you know how to run the ABC's business better than it does, by all means go along and get a job as a tea lady and see how you go. I am sure it will take a long time before they put you in any position of responsibility. In the meantime, maybe you could start by reading Senator Schacht's submission, which still has not seen the light of day. It is probably in desperate need of upgrading. If you want any help, just give us a yell. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security, and it relates to receipt of British pensions. Would you mind telling the Senate if there is any financial impact on people currently in receipt of British pensions as a result of the United Kingdom non‐indexation of pensions? What is the government's attitude to these pensions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Knowles very much for the question, because it is a very important question for former British residents living in Australia on British pensions.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Hill and opposition senators.

—The United Kingdom in fact is the only country which has a social security agreement with Australia which does not index its pensions to its former residents in Australia. It also does not index its pensions to its former residents who go to other Commonwealth countries. Senators might be interested to know that the United Kingdom does index its pensions to those of its people who have gone to live in the United States. They treat them differently. They are obliged by the EU's rules to index their pensions to any of their expatriates who go to live in EU countries and, interestingly, they were prepared not very long ago to sign an agreement with the Philippines to index the pensions of any Britons who go to live in the Philippines.

PARA.BREAK: Australia also indexes any pensions of its expatriates who go overseas, and all our other agreement partners index the pensions of expatriates in Australia. The comparison is extraordinary. We are talking about pensions to which British people have contributed throughout their working lives in the United Kingdom. It is a superannuation pension; it is not a pension just paid by the taxpayer. Yet they do not receive any increase to their pension, in some cases over many years of living in Australia, simply because, for exam ple, they have come to Australia to live with their extended family.

ANSWER.PARA: These British pensioners are clearly very disadvantaged by the freezing of their pensions. The average UK pension paid into Australia now is less than $40 a week. I just do not know how the United Kingdom government can live with the shame of that. This decision of the UK government that has been running over a long time has implications for Australia and for the Australian taxpayer. But this government has a firm commitment to look after our elderly residents. Let me make it absolutely clear that the government will continue to top up the pensions of former UK residents affected by the lack of indexation of pensions paid into Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is now what they are saying in the west.
—That is not what Mr Beazley, the Leader of the Opposition, is saying in the west. That is not what Labor is saying to people in the election campaign.

ANSWER.PARA: The non‐indexation of these pensions costs the Australian taxpayers $80 million a year. On top of that, we are also paying for—and are glad to pay for—the Medicare costs, the health care costs and the aged care costs of these British pensioners in Australia. The previous government and previous governments going back many years have tried to do something about this iniquitous situation. It was one area in which I thought there would have been bipartisan support for the action which I have been taking in recent times.

I had a meeting with the UK minister while I was there recently. Who went with me? The Australian High Commissioner to the United Kingdom, a former Minister for Social Security, Dr Neal Blewett, who has himself made representations on this matter for many years and is a firm believer that Britain should honour its pensioners. On behalf of Australia, he will be giving evidence to the House of Commons select committee which is inquiring into this matter at the moment and he will be heard this month. Under the proposal which I took to Minister Lilley, all future migrants to this country would get their pensions indexed and at the same time we in Australia would continue to top up the pensions of those who are already receiving pensions in this country under the previous arrangements. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I would like to ask Minister Newman a supplementary question because I have here Mr Beazley's newsletter which severely misrepresents so many of the issues relating to her portfolio. Minister, I was wondering whether you would like to set the record straight and tell the Senate exactly what government policy is in relation to your policy area.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I have got one minute to go through all those. The opposition leader said that we would reduce pensions by fiddling with the average weekly earnings benchmark. What have we done? We have set aside money in the current budget and future budgets for pension increases to guarantee it.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Beazley said that pensioners would face dental charges of $200 an hour. Again, that is wrong. Pensioners retain free access to state government dental care. Labor has also said that older people would need to sell their home to get into nursing homes. That again is wrong. Guarantees have been provided by the minister that homes will not need to be sold. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Ray seems to have gone into the travel agency business. He obviously knows a lot more about my plans than I do.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are doing cultural things over the weekend.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are far too many interjections.

—As I was saying, I would have hoped that, after 13 years in government, those on the other side would appreciate—at least to some extent—the benefits of ensuring that you are up to date on developments offshore, particularly in areas of relevance to your portfolio responsibilities. ANSWER.PARA: If you wanted to go to one of the world's leading conferences you would get yourself tickets to Hawaii and come along, and I will see what I can do to ensure that they take you seriously. At least Senator Kernot is tracking the issue.

Unless you do go overseas, open your minds and expand your horizons a bit, you will wallow in opposition for ever and a day. You will end up where poor old Senator Carr is where you spend all your time consumed in bitterness and hatred, trying to demolish your factional colleagues and trying to ensure that a micro faction becomes a mini‐micro faction—all to no avail.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —I made it clear that Hawaii is in relation to a very important media conference, a telecommunications conference. This is like saying that the ALP should not have gone to Terrigal for the national conference some years ago.

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are far too many interjections. I am sure Senator Ray expects a serious answer to this question and he should be able to hear it.

—I wish I shared your touching commitment regarding Senator Ray's motivations on this matter, Madam President. The fact is I am sure Senator Ray and his colleagues would be squealing like cut cats if we actually released the Mansfield report on 24 December, because that is not a sensible time. It was an old trick of yours to dump these late on a Friday night or get them out on a Sunday morning over the Christmas period. We do not believe in doing that. We want to see proper and sensible debate. So if the Mansfield report is going to be looked at seriously, it ought to be looked at in real time. I do not want to have to send it off to you at the Gold Coast, to Senator Faulkner at his beach shack or to anyone else who might not be able to concentrate on it seriously. —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. In last week's `Social Security compliance report' you implied that more than $300 million in savings were recovered by a crackdown on alleged cheats and rorters. How do you reconcile that with table 1 of the report which shows that deliberate fraud by social security recipients involved only $4.7 million? Isn't it true that most overpayments result from system complexity, the department's failure to communicate its requirements to customers and different interpretations of complex eligibility criteria? Do you, as Minister for Social Security, feel any obligation whatsoever to correct any false impression that you may have conveyed to the media and the Australian public?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Woodley for the question because I have seen some reports in the media which would suggest that things are not as they seem. I can assure Senator Woodley, as he would no doubt know, that the material which I presented was not produced in my office, it was produced by the Department of Social Security. Therefore, the questions that he raises question the accuracy, perhaps, or the honesty of my department; I am not sure.

ANSWER.PARA: Having said that, I would like to put it clearly on the record that at no time have I ever suggested that the majority of social security recipients are dishonest. It is a minority. But the way that we need to work to stop all of them being stigmatised is to crack down hard on what cheats there are, because cheats can run up a very large bill for the taxpayer quite fast. Some of them not only do it fast, but they do it for many years. There was a newspaper report today outlining the conviction of a woman who had been cheating the system for 13 years or thereabouts.

TALK.START.PARA: —One person.
—Yes, and one person can run up something like $160,000.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—It would sound as though the Labor Party—I am not sure about the Democrats—are supporting the cheats, not the taxpayers. The fact is that the claim of the Democrats, which has been reported, that 90 per cent of incorrect payments are caused by departmental error is just not true. About eight per cent of the debts are departmental error, and that is less than one per cent of total outlays.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Faulkner was also in the press putting his views on the compliance report that I produced a few days ago. He said that the compliance successes were as a result of the previous government's measures. Of course, that is not true. The report was about the first three months of this financial year compared with the first three months of the last financial year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why not the previous quarter?

—Because they have all gone up. They have gone up since there has been strong leadership at the government level. Senator Faulkner also said that the impressive results from the Department of Social Security in terms of compliance have been to do with the fact that there has been a growth in social security numbers. Of course, over that period there has been about two per cent growth in the numbers of people receiving benefits from the Department of Social Security, but in almost all the measures that I produced in the report, the result for the department has been over a 20 per cent increase in the recovery rate. Therefore, in a very real sense, the department has done well and has worked hard. You will recall that in this place I congratulated departmental officers who have put so much effort into this.

ANSWER.PARA: The government is determined that we will keep up this effort because we believe it is essential for those who are entitled to social security benefits to be seen by their neighbours, by the rest of the country, as being genuinely entitled. We do not want this small handful of people to bring such discredit to the social security system that it rubs off onto those who are entitled to benefits.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for admitting that it is a small percentage—by my calculation, about 1½ per cent—who are rorting the system. Why then, Minister, did the introductory comments in your letter contain phrases like `people are cheating on their fellow citizens'? You spoke about `recipients who rort the system'; you said you want to `stop the cheats'. Why is it, Minister, that your comments were clearly designed to give the impression that fraud on the department was out of control when, in fact, it is not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to be rude to Senator Woodley—I am sure he has a good heart tucked away in there—but the point is that I have always said that, whereas the majority of people are honest, a handful of people can not only bring the system into disrepute but also cost the taxpayer a lot of money. I stand by that. Those are the facts of the matter.

ANSWER.PARA: If we, in this little pink chamber here, think that the rest of this nation is not thinking along those lines, people in here are very deluded and have lost touch with the wider community. People are concerned that we have a social security system that is clean. So long as there are any people who are not declaring their earnings or who are claiming entitlement to pensions for which they are not entitled, the social security system will be a dishonoured system. I do not believe that this nation deserves a dishonoured system. The people who get the benefits should be believed to be honest and credible. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 November, in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, I tabled a response to a question asked by Senator Bob Collins. It has since been brought to my attention that information relating to the timing of the aircraft incident as supplied by Airservices—as supplied to the office of the minister for transport, as supplied to me—was incorrect. Airservices has now supplied supplementary advice and I seek leave to incorporate that advice in Hansard .

QUESTION.PARA: Leave granted.
The advice read as follows—
Airservices has provided the following supplementary advice:

. The commencement of the PADS training program involved a number of drops of PADS equipment at Jervis Bay in early November 1996. During the course of this exercise, a problem arose with the release aircraft.

. According to the Airservices incident report, the problem was related to the aircraft's automatic pilot and was not related to any of the PADS. There was some confusion within Airservices as to what stage this problem arose in the flight. The earlier advice provided by Airservices indicated that the incident arose during an approach to Nowra airport. This in incorrect.
. The problem arose during preparation for the second drop of PADS equipment and occurred on the "base leg" of the "drop" "circuit" being flown by the aircraft over the dropping zone.

. The incident referred to did not occur during an approach to Nowra airport. The problem became apparent during preparation for the second drop of PADS equipment. The problem caused an in‐flight emergency which necessitated the pilot making a landing at Nowra airport.

. The earlier advice was incorrect because of confusion about the use of the term "base leg" which refers both to the penultimate stage in preparing for a PADS drop and to the penultimate stage of an aircraft making an approach to an airport.
. In any event, following landing, the problem was apparently rectified and the training continued.
. Airservices regrets the inaccuracy of the earlier advice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

Then, when he actually resumes from leave, we find that the US leg of his trip is being squeezed because of the amount of time he is taking at the UK end.

We would cut a lot of slack for a minister organising an overseas trip but for his track record. His track record indicates total double standards.

He was happy at estimates committees to put questions on notice, to ask questions without notice, to bang in questions to a range of ministers when we were in government, with snide implications. When particular ministers actually took leave and paid for the whole thing themselves, it did not protect them from the sneering, patrician attitude of Senator Alston; it only encouraged him to attack people, suggesting they were wasting taxpayers' money, that they were on junkets. But the first opportunity he gets to put his snout in the trough, he is in there like a vacuum cleaner, sucking up taxpayers' money at the rate of knots, going to the old country, taking leave, then heading off for New York, timing it for right in the middle of a weekend so he can have another two days off. Then another day goes in travel to Los Angeles, but he is available only one morning in Los Angeles for one or two meetings before he goes off to Hawaii to attend a conference for half a day. I will bet you anything that he does not spend three days at the conference.

I regret raising this today because, by raising it, I have really killed off Senator Alston's holiday. `Senator Hulot's' holiday is down the drain. He will now fill the whole thing up with meetings to prove me wrong. I am going to love being proved wrong. I am going to love him coming back here and saying, `I worked like a dog overseas', because I have spoiled his fun.

TALK.START.PARA: —He worked like an aardvark.

—I acknowledge Senator Faulkner's interjection. We will now have a complete replanning of the itinerary. —Yes, that is the point, Senator Kernot? Who set the date? I bet it was Senator Alston. So I am going to be trudging round this country, apparently, right through January, doing all his work, while he is bludging overseas. Let me put on the record a bit of envy here. This minister, while in opposition, asked a whole range of embittered, cynical questions on travel. You can get up next, because you used to interject, Senator Patterson, on those matters. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I presume—
—The big guns have come out.
—If you listen, Senator Carr, you might learn something. I thought that Senator Ray moved to take note of all answers given by Senator Alston. Is that correct?
—Yes, that is correct.

—If that is correct, may I address the question that he answered from Senator Kernot regarding the shares in public enterprises being sold out to private enterprise. She was amazed that shares in some of those former government assets had risen to a high amount and said what a disgrace it was that the government sold off such things.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe the shares are pushed up by the fact that thinking investors out there look at the stock that is available and can see coming out of such a move better private enterprise management and a better thinking privatised board. That is why those shares go up. The converse can also apply—that, if you have not got a good board and private enterprise management, the shares will go the other way.

What is wrong, Senator Kernot, with those shares going up? In the case of Telstra, for instance, where only a third of the shares or assets are being sold off, if they go up 20 per cent so does the rest of the asset, which remains in the hands of the government. You get better dividends and all that sort of thing returning to the government. I cannot understand why the Democrats, or anyone else, decry the fact that shares in X government enterprises go up a big or reasonable amount. Investors look at what is behind the company. For instance, in Western Australia, there are a couple of CEOs or chairmen of boards whom I am happy to invest in no matter where they go because they take their management skills with them. The same happens with assets that used to belong to the government.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Kernot went on to speak further about what a disgrace something was. I forget what it was but she said it went up by a certain amount and that was lost to the Australian taxpayers or to Australians in general. That is not quite right, Senator Kernot, because what happens when they eventually sell their shares—if they sell them? First of all I will talk about the dividends. Generally, a higher priced company which is doing better will return a better dividend. Those dividends get taxed. That is one side. But people may eventually sell the shares off at an inflated price. Say they went up by 30 or 40 per cent. By any stretch of the imagination, about 48 per cent of that will go straight back to the Australian Taxation Office, which is for all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —A 48 per cent return on a 100 per cent loss.

—So even if there was a massive rise, as you said, 48 per cent of that massive rise will go back to the Australian people via the taxation department. You look at the whole picture and see what goes back into the government coffers. I said 48 per cent on your capital gains on any shares sold. Of course, you have the bigger value of the shares that are left in government hands. You have to look at all those things—not just get up and criticise. The fact is that when a government, whether our government or the former government, sells something off it keeps returning dividends into the public purse again. That is something you ought to take note of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the motion moved by Senator Robert Ray that the Senate take note of the answers given by Senator Alston to various questions today. TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the motion of Senator Robert Ray, noting all answers by the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) in question time today. Senator Alston, in one of his most extraordinary performances in recent times, announced to the Senate that, as far as he was concerned, everyone can afford to have shares. Of course, he is taking his place in the millionaires alley across the other side of the chamber when he seeks to demonstrate that. There was, quite clearly, an undervaluing of the assets that they are seeking to privatise in Telstra.

SPEECH.PARA: He stated that there must be occasions when you leave something for those that come after. This was not some new found conservation drive that he was seeking. What he was seeking to do was to protect the future exploitation of one of Australia's great public assets. He is not some sort of born‐again greenie. What he was seeking to do was to protect the profiteers seeking to get their hands on Telstra.

Of course, this follows a pattern for him. You do not see the same sorts of attitudes being expressed when it comes to the ABC. There is no interest there in protecting the assets of Australia. There is no interest being expressed there about ensuring that there is something for those that come after and ensuring that there is the protection of one of the most valuable institutions in this country—the ABC. What this government has done is impose cuts of some $209 million over four years. The minister stands in this Senate like Pontius Pilate, washing his hands of the consequences of those deliberate acts to undermine the ABC.

What is the pattern there? From the very night of the election we saw this government announcing that they did not intend to cut the ABC. Then, straight after the election, they made it perfectly clear that that was their intention all along. It was their intention. Despite what they told this Senate and despite what they told the electorate before the election about their intentions to defend the ABC, the reality is that they have embarked upon a program of quite deliberately undermining and attacking the ABC at every possible turn.

What you see in a number of statements by the government at a senior level—from the minister, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Treasurer (Mr Costello)—is that they have all indicated their determination to undermine the capacity of the ABC to meet its comprehensive broadcast responsibilities—to undermine the charter of the ABC in such a manner as to be able to reduce the effectiveness of the ABC in such a manner that it will reduce public confidence, ultimately, in the ABC.

What you notice is that the Prime Minister told Fran Kelly from the ABC that the ABC was politically correct to a fault and that there tends to be a concentration around one particular point of view. You saw the Treasurer, Mr Costello, believe there was a lack of accountability. You saw the minister himself say that he thought the budget was very bloated and that they could sustain a 10 per cent cut without a reduction in efficiency or service.

Quite clearly, what is happening in terms of the reduction in service is that those understandings are not possibly being met. They could not be met. It was quite impossible for them to be met. What else would you expect? You cannot possibly take $209 million out of the budget of the ABC, which has a budget of some $500 million per year, and not affect the quality of service.

We in opposition have seen many members of the Liberal Party complaining bitterly about the concentration of resources in Sydney. What you notice is a direct result of the budget decisions being taken by this government. The ABC has no choice but to remove services from other parts of this country. We have a situation now in my city, Melbourne, where the circumstances are that there is a continuing networking of programs to the extent that we cannot even get a local weather report.

This is the great institution being reduced in this manner by the actions of this government and by a minister that stands in here and says, `Of course, all Australians can afford shares.' We cannot afford an ABC. We cannot afford a decent service that allows for very basic entitlements that this country has a right to expect, and that is a comprehensive broadcasting service.

This is a government that is determined, as they said, in turn, when they appointed the new chair and the secretary to the department, Mr Neville Stevens, who wrote to the remuneration tribunal saying:

. . . the new chair will have significant responsibilities. The chair will be required to refocus the ABC, narrowing the range of its activities to concentrate more clearly on its public service role.

We know what that means now—that if you are in Melbourne on a Saturday night, you cannot get a local weather report because your services are coming out of Sydney. That is what they mean by `refocus the ABC' and `narrowing the range of its activities to concentrate more clearly on its public service role'. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston), said in his answer to my question today—and Senator Panizza said it also—that the Democrats are against anyone making a profit on shares. We were making a distinction between ordinary shares and windfall profits—overnight profits to the tune of $3.3 billion for German private shareholders at the expense of the German public purse, $3.2 billion in the case of Britain and $558 million in the case of the Australian public purse and the sale of the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories.

Senator Panizza argued that you get 48 per cent back at some stage through taxpayers paying tax on shares. What a great return that is! How many shares you buy depends on how much you have. `It is a judgment for all to make,' he said. Try to tell that to the coalition's battlers! That is what is wrong with this policy. It is very bad policy. It is bad enough to sell Telstra. It is very bad economic policy to sell it for at least 20 per cent below cost and to visit a loss of $1.6 billion on the taxpayers of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The necessity for the recommendations of the cross‐party Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee report on the proposed lifting of bans on imported cooked chicken into Australia to be implemented in full by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy.

Today we are addressing a matter of extreme urgency. I want to point out that there are two issues. One is the issue of urgency and the other is contained in the motion itself—that is, the necessity for the recommendations to be implemented in full. I believe that these two matters are the subject of this debate, and certainly they ought to be.

Why is this matter urgent? It is urgent because all of the signals are that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) is going to ignore the Senate report and its recommendations and allow the importation of cooked chicken meat into this country—against the advice of every single one of the farmer organisations, against the advice of all of the chicken producers in this country and against the advice of the peak bodies.

I believe this is a gross dereliction of duty on the minister's part. Instead of listening to what is being said to him, objections—proper objections which have been raised—have been met on every occasion with abuse. Let me read to the Senate a notice of motion that I moved in this place some weeks ago. It says:
. . . the Senate—

(a) notes that, in answer to a question on 5 November 1996, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) announced that `the Government was determined to seriously consider allowing imports of cooked chicken meat'—

That was before the minister had read the report, before he had responded to its recommendations and before the Nairn report had been handed down. Let me point out that the Nairn report has still not been tabled in this place, in spite of the fact that it quite clearly was leaked to certain sections of the media.

So the people whom the minister is supposed to represent—the people whom he abuses—were not allowed to see the report upon which he based his abuse. The parliament, which is supposed to consider this issue, has been ignored, and a very responsible report by this Senate—I might underline that by saying that it was a unanimous report of all the parties represented—has been ignored by the minister.
But that is not the end of the matter. Let me read what an Australian article reported the minister as saying a couple of days ago about chicken growers in this country. The article said:

. . . yesterday, Mr Anderson launched a stinging attack on the chicken industry for its continued opposition to an AQIS recommendation that imports of cooked chicken meat be allowed into Australia from the United States, Thailand and Denmark.

Referring to opponents of the move as "immature reactionaries", Mr Anderson told The Australian he was "fed up" with their inability to look at the future of the industry in a broader context of world trade and quarantine realities.

Let me remind the Senate that Mr Anderson was not talking about a bunch of trade unionists out on strike against some primary industry or other. He was not talking about his political opponents. He was not speaking about a group of terrorists trying to destroy the country. He was speaking about people he is supposed to represent. He was talking about farmers who quite naturally believe in their own industry and want to continue farming.

Can they draw the title of immature reactionaries? I would suggest that there are a lot of people in this country who believe in farmers and who want to continue farming. Are they all immature reactionaries, simply because they want to protect their own industries?

Let me add to this. In August 1995, Mr Anderson wrote to Mr John Clarke, President of the Victorian Farmers Federation Chicken Meat Group. He pointed out just how concerned the coalition was about AQIS. His letter states:

. . . the Coalition has for some time been concerned about the quality of the investigative work carried out by AQIS. Our concerns have been heightened in recent weeks by comments from senior CSIRO scientists who have referred to a brain drain in AQIS and suggested there are serious deficiencies in our quarantine arrangements.
He continued:

I believe that the extent of concern raised about the adequacy of AQIS's quarantine risk assessment process warrants a thorough investigation, and in the case of Newcastle Disease the conduct of an extensive Environmental Impact Statement.
Of course, having been elected to government, all of a sudden the commitments given in that letter have disappeared.

Let me remind the Senate that almost every one of the peak bodies concerned with this issue agree with the Senate and its report. They would urge the minister to take note of what is being said, to read the report and to implement its recommendations. Lex Buchanan, from the Queensland Farmers' Federation, says:

BREAK.PARA: Recommendations by the Senate Committee inquiry into the administration of all aspects of the importation of cooked chicken meat into Australia pave the way for significant and long overdue changes to the way quarantine issues are managed by AQIS.

"Rural industry in Queensland fully understands the trade implications of raising and lowering quarantine barriers under the new international trading arrangements," he said. "We have had this trumpeted to us by Government officials for long enough. Unfortunately those same officials do not appear to be listening to industry and the community who are saying that there are other considerations in addition to trade matters which must also be taken into account."
The New South Wales Farmers' Association put out a press release, which says:
The NSW Farmers' Association has called on Primary Industries Minister, John Anderson, to reconsider the proposed importation of cooked chicken meat into Australia.

This follows the release of recommendations from a Senate Committee for more tests to be carried out on whether the commercial processing of foreign chicken meat can prevent the entry of Newcastle Disease.
"NSW Farmers' has always been concerned about the scientific basis of AQIS's decision on this matter and these concerns have been echoed to some degree by this report," Mr Comensoli said.
The Queensland farmers and the New South Wales farmers agree with the report of the Senate inquiry. The Minister for the Environment in New South Wales put out a press release which said:
The State Government today launched a public education campaign on the deadly dangers of imported cooked chicken products to the poultry industry and native birds.
Environment Minister Pam Allan said the campaign was the result of a resolution passed by parliament earlier this year.
"This Federal Government decision will destroy jobs on the Central Coast, Hunter and rural areas of this state," said Ms Allan.
"The plan to introduce cooked chicken products from Denmark, Thailand and the USA could introduce the deadly Newcastle disease into Australia.
"Imported meat is a real threat to local jobs, as this industry employs 17,000 people nationally," Ms Allan said.
"The Federal Government's action flies in the face of the advice from the all party Senate Committee for Rural and Regional Affairs.

Everybody around this country, except the minister, seems to understand the concern that our own chicken growers have. I could go on and add to what I have just read to you by quoting the concern of the Australian Conservation Foundation and the Nature Conservation Council of New South Wales.

People who often are on opposite sides of the fence are united on this issue. What is the consistent recommendation they are giving? They are saying to the minister, `For goodness sake, before you make this decision, take note of the recommendations of that Senate inquiry.' It is urgent that the minister hears the voice of the Senate again today on this matter, that he listens to what the Senate is saying to him and that he takes account of the recommendations which were made. Added to that urgency is the fact that not only is our own poultry industry under threat but Newcastle disease infects many different species. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill, Sen David

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Trade and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue of Australia's quarantine policy is critically important. It is one which is critical not only to rural and regional Australia and our primary producers but also to all Australians in terms of the contribution to agriculture, to the Australian economy and to our export efforts. It is in this context that we are discussing Senator Woodley's motion today.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's national interest in quarantine policy has two dimensions. The first is to protect the health of humans, plants, animals, fisheries and our natural and built environments through a conservative, disciplined and scientific approach to quarantine, including effective border controls and assessment of import access requests. The second is to safeguard and enhance our trading interests, including gaining access to export markets by conforming with the international obligation that Australia has, and in which it has been instrumental in establishing and adopting relevant international systems and standards.

As the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) has made clear on numerous occasions, this government has no intention of moving away from a conservative approach to quarantine policy justified on scientific grounds. If the science does not add up, then the product will not be allowed entry—contrary to a view I sometimes hear expressed. AQIS is constantly refusing requests for import or is turning shipments around because they do not conform with our strict import protocols. This has included recent well‐publicised cases of rejected shipments of fertilisers and farm machinery as well as fruit and other products from the Pacific, Africa and the subcontinent.

Equally, as Senator Cook and Senator Bob Collins will well appreciate, Australia has worked hard to put in place a set of international arrangements through the WTO sanitary and phytosanitary agreement which seek to ensure that quarantine is not used as a non‐tariff barrier. The same international rules which have required Australia to address, in a timely way, import access requests for products previously restricted by quarantine barriers are being aggressively used by Australian negotiators to open up significant new access opportunities for Australian products in other markets. Given that Australia exports five times more food than it imports, this is clearly in our national interest.

In 1995-96, AQIS was successful in gaining access for nearly 70 products in 38 markets. These included poultry and poultry products into Malaysia, citrus products into Thailand—estimated to be worth $1 million in the first year—and rising citrus exports from the Riverina and Sunraysia into California and Florida.

Let us be under no doubt about the importance of the issues for our primary industry sector and the communities of rural and regional Australia. Our approach is under careful scrutiny internationally. As the minister has said recently, our current negotiations with the EU over the new veterinary arrangements will have a direct impact on our $400 million agriculture export trade with Europe. It is against this background that we need to address the issue of proposed imports of cooked chicken meat.

This chamber well knows that this is an important request that has been under assessment for six years. The IRA was completed in 1994, including detailed work on the science of the cooking proposal. The previous minister was advised by AQIS in May 1995 that the scientific assessment was complete and that under strict conditions imports would be permitted. He noted this advice and did not challenge it. He apparently was going to undertake some final consultation with industry. We can only speculate on what he did.

This is the situation Minister Anderson inherited. He held consultations with industry in May and June and initiated two government‐industry working groups to enable final consultation on the technical quarantine protocols to be applied and on the possible economic adjustment which might need to be considered as a result of cooked chicken meat imports, which are estimated to comprise between two and five per cent of domestic chicken consumption.

Independent scientific advice confirms AQIS's time‐temperature parameters. The industry has also confirmed in writing that they agreed the cooking parameters will deactivate diseases of concern. The minister has to weigh this evidence, along with the view of the Senate committee. As non‐scientists, they did not consider it appropriate or wise to arbitrate on the scientific issue. Indeed, they noted that AQIS had put forward a considerable amount of evidence supporting the view that the science is sound—consisting of reputable, scientifically based opinions, including those of most of the state veterinary authorities.

The Australian Animal Health Laboratory, the Bureau of Resource Sciences and Dr Dennis Alexander, a renowned national virologist, support AQIS's view. Nevertheless, the committee recommended cooking tests be done on chicken products in collaboration with industry. This will need to be considered. The minister also has to weigh up this view in the light of strong industry concerns about the introduction of Newcastle disease in cooked chicken meat. Requests have also been received from the same industry to ease the import arrangements for hatching eggs from Denmark, where there have been recent occurrences of the Newcastle disease. It is interesting to note that the company concerned noted that ill‐informed rumours have circulated in the Australian industry regarding the biosecurity of allowing the hatching egg shipment to proceed.

The industry has also expressed concern about the import protocols and the question of the inspection of processing plants. With regard to the Thai plants, it is interesting that a consultant representing the Chicken Growers Council said before the Senate committee inquiry into AQIS in November 1995:
. . . their plants are as well equipped, or better equipped, than our plants. So there is no Third World status in terms of the Thai food processing industry.

The Senate committee expressed its satisfaction that AQIS's approach to processing contamination is appropriate. The committee went on to observe that industry had been slow to understand and accept the basis of certification procedures between trading countries and the difficulties that Australian exporters would undoubtedly face if such procedures were discontinued. Nevertheless, the committee recommended that the plants in all countries proposing to export chicken to Australia should be inspected. This will also need to be considered carefully by the minister.

Importantly, the committee also recommended that the Quarantine Act be amended and that final responsibility for quarantine decisions be placed in the hands of the minister and/or the government. The committee goes on to recognise that any decisions must be consistent with the provisions of the agreement. This is a very important issue and one that needs to be weighed up carefully by the government, along with the many recommendations in this area made by the Nairn committee of review whose report will be released shortly.

BREAK.PARA: In summary, I reiterate that the Senate committee report is under active consideration by the minister. Given the short time since its delivery to the Senate—less than two months—and given the previous government's very tardy track record in responding to committee reports from RARAC, animal welfare and other committees, I suggest that the Senate be patient and allow the minister time for due and proper consideration of all the issues in light of what I have raised here today.

It is on that basis that the government must oppose Senator Woodley's motion. This motion demands a decision be made ahead of the Nairn report being released. It demands a decision be made by the minister in a time frame of weeks and not months rather than the years taken by the previous government on a variety of issues. As I said at the beginning of my speech, there is no argument that quarantine issues are of vital concern not only to this chamber but also to all Australians. No-one is more acutely aware of that than the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I think if Senator Woodley had waited to see how the minister takes up all the suggestions that have been made—

TALK.START.PARA: —We have seen it.
—If you waited until he gave his reply to those recommendations, I believe that you would have been much better placed.

BREAK.PARA: We will be opposing this urgency motion. We have taken into consideration the recommendations, some of which are very good and some of which are not quite so easy to implement. If you want to keep quarantine inspection out of politics and if you want to still allow our product to get into other countries, you should not politicise this debate too much.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Brownhill) on the moderate response which he has just delivered on behalf of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson). If the minister had responded in similar style, I suspect we would not be here this afternoon debating this urgency motion—and I see Senator Woodley nodding in assent. I know that the parliamentary secretary has a job to do on behalf of his minister. I also know about the personal representations that the parliamentary secretary has made to his incompetent minister on this issue. I know about the representations that he has made on behalf of this Australian industry—and I am pleased to say one of the few bits of the Australian food industry still substantially owned by Australians—to this fumbling, bumbling minister who has made a mess of this issue from day one.

SPEECH.PARA: The parliamentary secretary did not attempt to defend the outrageous abuse which has been heaped on the leaders of this important Australian industry which employs thousands of Australians. It is one of the biggest—if not the biggest—industries in the Hunter Valley. It is bigger than the wine industry in the Hunter Valley. It is one of the most substantial Australian industries.

When the Australian leaders of this Australian industry that provides thousands of Australians with permanent work had the temerity to stand up for their own industry—and the minister might have disagreed with the position they were taking—what was the minister's response? It was to heap gratuitous abuse on them in the national newspapers of this country.

When I read this I was honestly surprised. I was so surprised by what the minister had to say that I checked it in parliament. I gave the minister an opportunity to correct the record and to say he had been misreported. Honourable senators would remember I put a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Parer—and I see Senator Woodley nodding assent. The minister said that the minister confirms the accuracy of the quotations in the newspapers.

The minister said that the leaders of this Australian industry were `infantile opportunists'—people who could not see the future of their own industry. You can imagine the reaction of the people in this industry—I know them only too well; in many cases they have been doing this for a living for their entire lives—to that piece of gratuitous abuse heaped on them by the minister for primary industries. How then do you reconcile the difference in the minister's attitude to this industry and his own industry, the grain industry, where he is a producer? He pulled the plug—and this is a quarantine issue—on imported grain trials.

During the height of the drought when things were very bad—thankfully they are not that bad any longer—and grain had gone beyond $300 a tonne, grain farmers around Australia were hoarding grain on their properties. Who could blame them? They were having a very hard time and the price was going up $10 a day. They were hanging on to it a bit longer.

When the feedlot industry and the consumer industries in Australia were desperate in terms of the prices they could no longer afford, we announced as a government, rightly, that we would carefully consider the importation of grain under strict quarantine conditions. ABARE in fact measured the response. Within two weeks of that announcement the price had dropped something like $50 a tonne because people thought, `We had better not hang on to it any longer', and that is why we did it in government.

We instituted careful trials to provide a protocol—not to necessarily import grain now—to provide the basis for these important feedlot and chicken industries in Australia that depend on grain. On the basis that you get at least one major doubt every 10 years in this country, we did not want this crisis to occur again. So we put into place a careful trial to at least lay down the protocols for the importation of grain to keep these vital Australian industries going. The future of the Australian beef industry is with the expansion of the feedlot industry in Australia, not the contraction of it.

What was the minister's response to this? Within weeks of taking office—I mean weeks—he pulled the plug on the grain trials. What happened to free trade then, parliamentary secretary? What happened to all the GATT conditions there? They went out the door. It was closed borders as far as the minister was concerned. Little wonder the chicken industry is now asking: `free trade or fowl play?' in respect of this minister. Have a look at the public record. On 17 April, within weeks of the 2 March election, the minister said this about the grain trials:
I am prepared to have the panel—
that is, the assessment panel—
meet again on this matter but would indicate clearly that I believe the suspended trial should now be abandoned.
I will be advising the panel there will be no further Commonwealth support for the trial.

There was no doubt in anyone's mind that that statement by the minister ended the imported grains trial. Let me tell you, that was the finish of it. We have kept in close touch with those consumer industries of grain in Australia, and nothing has happened since. It has all been put on hold. I daresay we will go through the same circus next time we have a major drought in this country. On the issue of quarantine for imported grain, as far as the minister was concerned it was brick walls up all around Australia. The barriers were there. It was closed borders, finished.

I have always said that what we should be looking at are the social, economic and environmental implications of Australia's obligations under the Uruguay Round of GATT.

This motion is for the Senate to demand full implementation of the committee recommendations. While I certainly believe that the implementation of these recommendations would be a good idea, I do not think that they are of themselves enough to give me confidence to believe that it will lead to the importation of cooked chicken meat being a safe option. This is just basic good sense, since real conditions will be markedly different from those where procedures are undertaken by trained scientists in a laboratory.

Let us look at the issues here. My concern is that real conditions may vary considerably, and not just because of the difference between laboratory and commercial equipment, or because of the volume and speed of handling. We also need to consider that equipment will be run for years and that failure to remain within required parameters does not always result in equipment stoppage.

There is also pressure, especially in developing nations, to make do and mend and keep equipment running. The focus is liable to be to keep production going as fast as possible, rather than keep it as free as possible from variations that might allow avian disease to arrive. This is especially the case where workers are not well educated, and education and training focuses on production rather than on sanitary measures.

So what are the real issues? We have had a debate about cooked chicken meat and we have had a debate about salmon. We are having the debate now about industry self‐regulation and inspection. I have brought to the Senate issues of Codex Alimentaire. That is part of what we signed to under the Uruguay Round of GATT, which translates to the lowest common denominator. It also translates to different methods of handling issues like foot and mouth disease. Senator Bob Collins mentioned it could be a tariff barrier that would protect us. The interesting thing is that that is part of the agreement under the World Trade Organisation.

First of all, a nation like Australia has to prove there is a problem, and that becomes extremely difficult until there is a problem. So proving there is a problem when there is not yet a problem is extremely difficult. That militates against the precautionary principle. Secondly, Australia would have to prove that quarantine is the least restrictive method of dealing with it. That also becomes extremely difficult. If we are left only with the potential of using tariffs, and if the minister has ruled that out, then maybe we have to realise that it is time Australia did look at the implications of so‐called free trade. We should find out whether it is fair trade and what the implications—social, environmental and economic—are, so that we can argue intelligently on world fora in relation to what the future might be. We should get intelligent input into whatever the next round is. They are talking about the environment. Maybe this is the kind of thing which we have to argue positively for in Australia—that it is not good enough, the implications were not clearly seen in Australia and other nations when we signed. TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Trade and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Brownhill) on behalf of the government in speaking against Senator Woodley's urgency motion. The importance of quarantine practices and processes cannot be underestimated. As a senator from Tasmania, I am especially concerned to ensure that nothing is done which could compromise the disease‐free status of Tasmania, a competitive market advantage which cannot be overestimated. The Tasmanian economy is small, has few competitive advantages when it engages in world trade and, consequently, the maintenance of the agricultural advantages of Tasmania are paramount to my state.

SPEECH.PARA: As senators would be aware, two important agricultural industries in Tasmania are the apple industry and the aquaculture industry, particularly salmon raising. One is a long‐time signature industry for Tasmania, the other is an exciting emerging industry of world renown. As senators would also be well aware, both industries are presently involved in investigations by AQIS. These investigations involve the assessment of the potential risk of various diseases being introduced into Australia if action is taken to allow certain foreign products to be imported.

At present, the relevant investigations are at different stages of consideration. I will not go into the details here in respect of those investigations as the process, particularly for the salmon industry, has been long and not without controversy. Rather, I would like to focus on the reason why we should accept and indeed welcome these investigations and why we must continue to stress the importance of scientific assessment and evaluation.

Whether we like it or not, we live in an age where trade in products is competitive and there is the possibility for all the peoples of the world to buy and sell their products on a world market. This is particularly the case for agricultural and rural products. Australian meat, cereals, fruit, wines, fish, cheese, sugar and numerous other products are exported throughout the world for the consumers of the world who demand quality at a reasonable price.

BREAK.PARA: Naturally, we Australians know that our agricultural products are, at the very least, comparable to the very best available anywhere. We want all the nations of the world to buy our products. Trade brings great income to Australia. It brings jobs and it secures the future for our children. Given that trade offers these benefits, should we be surprised that other nations want to sell their products to Australia?

If we want to enjoy the benefits of international trade, we have to accept the trade rules that have been negotiated between nations in the World Trade Organisation. We are too small to go it alone. Those rules require, quite reasonably, that nations do not create artificial barriers to trade. Artificial restrictive access policies, which may be good short‐term domestic politics, will do us more harm than good in the long term. This is not to say that we do not have the right to protect our natural environment from disease. We have an obligation to demonstrate that our quarantine restrictions are validly established and justifiable. That is, we must be able to show, through scientific evidence, that our refusal to allow another country's products into our land is based on a real risk to our natural environment.

The obligation to undertake this assessment derives from agreements reached in the GATT Uruguay Round. Australia's commitment to the sanitary and phytosanitary agreement of the WTO imposes five requirements on us as a nation: firstly, quarantine decisions must have a sound scientific and technical basis; secondly, those decisions must flow from a proper process of risk assessment; thirdly, AQIS must adopt a consistent approach to risk management, that is, not arbitrarily adjust the acceptable level of risk from case to case; fourthly, the access decisions must be designed to achieve the determined level of risk in the least trade restrictive way; and, fifthly, the decision making process must be transparent and open.

Those obligations are no more than Australians would reasonably ask of any other nation on this earth. Put simply, these obligations require that we use the best science available to assess what risk the importation of a product imposes on our country, make a determination of what is an acceptable level of risk and then stick with this outcome.

Naturally, there will always be a difference of opinion among people, particularly politicians, as to what is an acceptable level of risk. Some people accept no level of risk. What these people have to accept is that such an isolationist approach to world trade will mean that our country is excluded from selling our agricultural products to others.

It should be remembered that, as a result of the GATT Uruguay round, it was estimated that Australia would benefit from an increase of around $1 billion per year in agricultural exports. Taking the isolationist approach not only puts this growth at risk but also imperils our present rural exports of over $20 billion a year. At the other extreme would be those few people who might suggest that we simply open our shores to all foreign products regardless of risk. This view, too, would be a disaster for Australia, and my state in particular.

In between these extremes is the rational understanding of risk as a feature of life. This view suggests that we should look both at the possibility of an event occurring and the consequences of that event. Whether the risk is such that action should be taken to prevent the possible event should then be considered. This is rational and reasonable.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the request of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), I table a state ment on the attendance of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) at the recent APEC leaders meeting. I seek leave to incorporate the statement in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to it.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
I wish to report to the House on my recent visit from 22 to 26 November to the Philippines for the APEC leaders meeting.

This meeting marked the start of the hard work of turning APEC's free‐trade rhetoric into reality. It began to turn vision into action. I believe that the meeting was very successful both as a forum for leaders to exchange views and in making progress on APEC's trade agenda.

In Manila each APEC member economy tabled an individual action plan which set out steps each would take towards the Bogor commitment of free and open trade and investment for developing economies by 2020 and developed economies by 2010.

These plans were reviewed and recommended by APEC trade and foreign ministers at their meeting just before the leaders meeting. I want to thank Mr Downer and Mr Fischer for their contribution during the year to producing a successful outcome in Manila.

While for the most part the plans contain steps to which economies were already committed under the Uruguay Round or unilaterally, they provide proof that APEC economies remain committed to removing tariff and non‐tariff barriers to trade and to freeing up investment. They thus set an example we hope non‐APEC members will take note of.
I wish neither to exaggerate the achievements of the plans nor to undervalue them. They were a good beginning.

They contain some new commitments of direct and early benefit for Australian business which in turn will create jobs for Australians. That is why we will continue to press for greater liberalisation of trade.

For example, in the mining sector the Philippines will lift import restrictions on coal. Thailand will liberalise its natural gas market. In agriculture, Hong Kong will relax import restrictions on rice by 2000 and controls on the stockpiling of frozen meat and poultry. Japan will introduce new quarantine measures expected to expedite Australian exports of fruit and flowers.

There will be other new opportunities for Australian business in banking and investment where access has been improved. China, for example, has agreed to increase the number of licenses for foreign banking, insurance and securities organisa tions. Thailand will increase the number of joint ventures in the insurance sector. Singapore will gradually open up the domestic banking sector to greater participation by international financial institutions. And the Philippines will review foreign investment restrictions on investment institutions.

There are also promising new commitments with regard to opportunities for Australian professional services. Singapore will remove commercial presence restrictions on engineers and architects. Japan is to review laws relating to foreign lawyers operating in Japan. Korea will review restrictions on the commercial presence for foreign accounting firms and improve market access for foreign lawyers.

The plans provide for each economy a consolidated picture of liberalisation—in the case of some APEC economies for the first time—thereby giving a higher degree of certainty and transparency for business.
The plans also lay down a baseline for the future. In a rolling process, the plans will be continually reviewed, updated and improved over the next 25 years.

The government will now do all it can to encourage the production of better plans over the next year or two. APEC leaders committed themselves in their declaration to improve them by the time they next meet in Vancouver next year. APEC trade ministers will review them next year and in doing so will take into account the views of the business community.

The government welcomes the increasing involvement of the business community in APEC as insurance that APEC will focus on business's needs. The government sees a major role for the APEC Business Advisory Committee in monitoring the improvement of the action plans of the member economies.

The business community has long asked governments to facilitate travel among member economies. I was pleased therefore to announce during the APEC meetings, agreement with Korea and the Philippines to trial Australia's proposal of an APEC business travel card which will provide business people with easier and faster access, including streamlined arrival arrangements. The government hopes that, once the trial has proved the worth of the scheme, other APEC members will join in.

Australia has already reduced tariffs and other barriers more than most member economies. Like every other government, mine will take account of what other economies are doing in deciding future steps. But our position is a positive one based on the assessment that liberalisation will bring overall benefits to the economy.

Australia's own action plan demonstrates the government's continuing commitment to trade liberalisation. This commitment is not a matter of ideology but a consequence of the government's conviction that liberalisation within the region will help sustain the region's economic growth, will open up increasing market opportunities for Australian exporters, will help promote Australia's own economic growth, and will create jobs and improve living standards in Australia.
APEC can help ease the costs of economic adjustment caused by liberalisation and globalisation through maximising the opportunities those same forces provide to increase our exports.

As I said in my first intervention during the leaders meeting, globalisation is the most potent economic force in the world today. It is important—in order to ensure public support for the economic and social adjustments that have to be made and to ensure that we can take advantage of the opportunities globalisation offers—that governments explain to their electorates the overall benefits of liberalisation.

A recent survey of Austrade's exporter clients showed that nearly 60 per cent either had increased employment or expected to do so as a result of exporting. Sixty‐four per cent said that they expected improved profitability as a result of exporting. Likewise, a survey of the growth and performance of small and medium sized enterprises survey released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics in September shows that a higher proportion of exporting businesses increased employment than non‐exporting businesses.

APEC's ambitions will be realised only if all participating economies continue to liberalise. Not every economy will move at the same pace in the same area. And APEC does not require mathematically precise reciprocity. But for APEC to work there has to be continual movement across all sectors, and all economies have to see the benefits for them. That is, in APEC language, the principles of comprehensiveness and comparability are important to the success of APEC's trade liberalisation process.

In that respect, I found the APEC leaders meeting encouraging. My impression was of a strong commitment to APEC and to the goal of free trade as the centrepiece of APEC. I was particularly heartened to hear the President of the United States repeat his support for maintaining the momentum of liberalisation, as expressed during his visit to Australia.

APEC is an important element in the government's efforts to improve market access, growth and employment—but only one element. Externally, APEC is only one strand of our trade policy which focuses also on gaining access at the bilateral and multilateral levels. APEC can be of assistance by providing opportunities for bilateral discussions on action plans and in imparting greater dynamism to the World Trade Organisation (WTO). The call by APEC leaders for the WTO to conclude an information technology agreement is one such example.

And in turn, the government's trade policy is only one element in its overall strategy to lift growth. Living cheek by jowl with the fast‐growing Asian economies does not assure us of success. We not only need the market access, we also need to be competitive.

The government's budget deficit reduction strategy, its reforms of the labour market and reduction of red tape are likewise important components of the government's programme to lift economic growth, employment and living standards. All of these are key ingredients in the government's approach to industry policy.
Mr Speaker

In Manila and at the leaders meeting itself, I took the opportunity to underline my government's commitment to engagement with our region—and to APEC as a core feature of that engagement. I reiterated that our participation would be whole‐hearted in achieving the trade and investment liberalisation goals laid down at Bogor. I emphasised my personal commitment to continuing the work of my predecessors who established APEC and suggested the leaders meeting.

APEC reflects the integration of the various strands in the government's regional policies. It demonstrates the mutually reinforcing roles played by our alliance with the United States and our partnerships with major Asian friends. It creates a sense of community among a very diverse group of economies by building on their common interests in promoting economic growth. It thus makes a very material contribution to the stability of our region.

The leaders meeting in particular is a most valuable institution—for Australia and the Asia‐Pacific region. It provides an unparalleled opportunity for face‐to‐face contact between leaders in the region. It helps underline shared interests in growth and stability. It has a special character which can only be maintained if there continues to be a personal commitment on the part of all leaders.

The authority and expectations that leaders bring to the APEC process are essential to maintaining the momentum of APEC's core trade and investment liberalisation agenda and delivering the results our business sector and communities at large look for.
One of the great strengths of the annual APEC meeting is the opportunity for the Australian prime minister to meet—in a very short period—a range of other leaders from our key regional partners.

I had a very useful and productive meeting with President Jiang Zemin of China. I was able to assure the president that the government saw close cooperation with China as important both politically and economically.

As very different societies we will not always see eye‐to‐eye on everything. But a strong relationship is mutually beneficial, given the substantial interests we have in common. I look forward to giving practical expression to this when I visit China next year.
The government sees China's full participation in regional and global structures as a force for stability.

I had a valuable first meeting with President Kim Young Sam. Korea is now our second‐largest export market and the ties between our countries, including at a people‐to‐people level, are growing strongly.

My meeting with Dr Mahathir built on my discussions with him earlier this year and enabled me to underline the strengths and value of the bilateral relationship with Malaysia. I hope to be able to pursue this further when I visit Malaysia in 1997.
I had good discussions with the prime minister of Singapore, Mr Goh Chok Tong, and I plan to visit his country also next year.

My meeting with Mr Chretien, the prime minister of Canada, enabled me to reaffirm our commitment to the traditionally close relationship between Australia and Canada. I look forward to attending the next leaders meeting under his chairmanship in Vancouver in 1997. His positive view of APEC's dynamism and capacity to produce results was encouraging.
I was able to renew my acquaintance with a number of other leaders, including the Japanese prime minister, Mr Hashimoto and President Soeharto. It was a pleasure to see them again.

Finally, I would like to thank President Ramos and the people of the Philippines for the generous hospitality they extended to me. President Ramos's strong and successful chairmanship of APEC during such a demanding year is a tribute to him and his government.

The holding of the APEC meetings in the Philippines gave me the opportunity to restate the value the government places on Australia's relations with the Philippines. It also allowed me to see at first hand something of the benefits of the substantial reforms President Ramos has introduced—and in particular, the rapid economic growth the Philippines is now enjoying.

I was pleased while in Manila to be able to speak at a reception held by the Australia‐New Zealand Chamber of Commerce and to meet many Australian business people who are seizing the opportunities in the Philippines.
I assure them, and all other business people operating in the APEC economies, of the government's interest in their success and the priority the government gives to doing all it can to support them.
